1.content:
Having just gotten home from a long day at work, I was hoping to have a quiet evening with my daughter. But those hopes were shattered when I saw the all too familiar car of Olivia’s boyfriend. I’d told her dozens of times that she couldn’t have people over while I wasn’t home; least of all her obnoxious 17-year-old boyfriend Kyle.

After parking the car in the garage, I walked into the house; only to find it empty. I began to wonder where they could be when I heard a thump come from upstairs. Of course, why am I not surprised. Placing my gun and police badge on the counter, I walked upstairs to find Olivia’s bedroom door closed. I reached out to open it; only to stop when I heard what I thought was moaning coming through the door. You’ve got to be kidding me!

Opening the door, I found Olivia lying topless on her bed with Kyle on top of her; the two of them making out with each other. Making my presence known, I said, “I hope I’m not interrupting anything.”

What followed was a chorus of cursing as Kyle and Olivia scrambled to get out of bed. Olivia quickly put her shirt back on; turning to me with an embarrassed look in her eyes. “Dad, I-I thought you were working late tonight?”

“I got off work early; thought we could spend some time together before you start school again.” Turning to Kyle, I said, “But I see you’ve already made plans.”

I never particularly liked Kyle Johnson; he was your stereotypical jock, thinking he was better than everyone else. My opinion of him was reinforced when he said, “Listen, man, we were just...”

“I know what you were doing, Kyle.” Getting annoyed, I said, “You were getting a little personal with my 15-year-old daughter.”

I should clarify something right now; Olivia isn’t my biological daughter. I started dating her mother shortly after she was born; her biological father wasn’t in the picture, so I was the only father she knew. After my wife died in a car crash a few years back, it became just the two of us.

Looking at me, Olivia said, “Dad, you’re overreacting; it’s not like we were having sex or anything.”

“Oh, so because you weren’t having sex that makes everything alright?” turning to Olivia, I said, “It’s bad enough that he’s an 18-year-old dating a minor; if I wanted to, I could have him arrested right now.”

Without acknowledging what I said, Kyle turned to Olivia and said, “Come on babe, let’s get out of here.”

Olivia hesitated for a moment; torn between listening to me and going off with her boyfriend. Looking at Kyle, she said, “I-I don’t know, maybe you should leave.”

“What?” scoffing, Kyle said, “Come on babe, you’re always complaining about how overprotective your Dad is.”

I watched as Kyle started to retrieve his and Olivia’s things. I knew enough to figure out what he was planning. Moving in front of the doorway, I said, “Kyle, if you leave here with my daughter I’ll have you charged with kidnapping.”

Despite my years as a deputy even I was surprised by what happened next; Kyle took a swing and punched me in the nose. As I stumbled back, Olivia ran towards me, “Daddy!”

Before she could get to me, Kyle grabbed her arm and pulled her out of the room. “Come on, we’re leaving.”

Once I regained my senses, I ran downstairs after them; as Olivia screamed at Kyle to let her go. Retrieving my gun, I ran out of the house just as Kyle peeled off down the street. Running to my car, I got in and started after them. Driving down the street, my lights flashing, I grabbed my police scanner and said, “This is Officer Sheppard; be on the lookout for a 2016 silver F150, license plate 327-XDC.” Turning onto the main road, I said, “Driver has assaulted an officer and taken a minor against her will.”

As I continued driving down the road, I had no idea that things were about to get weird.
1.title: How It Began

11.content:
Almost 20 minutes had gone by since I started chasing after Kyle and Olivia; despite the best efforts of myself and the other officers, we hadn’t found them yet. I was driving through some residential streets, hoping in vain to spot the truck, when I heard my cell phone ringing.

Grabbing it, I was relieved when I saw it was Olivia. Answering the phone, I said, “Olivia, honey, where are you?”

“Daddy, I-I...”

“Where are you, Olivia?”

“We-We’re on the access road leading to the dam.” Pausing, Olivia said, “Daddy, there’s something here that you need to see.”

Before I could say anything else, Olivia ended the call. Putting the phone back on the seat, I spun the car around and started towards the dam on the outskirts of town.

***************************


It was a 10 minute drive to the dam. After driving for about ½ a mile, I spotted Olivia waving at me from the side of the road. Stopping the car, I got out and ran over to her. Crying, Olivia came over and hugged me, “I-I’m sorry daddy.”

“It’s okay, sweetie,” kissing her head, I said, “Where’s Kyle?”

“W-We found something in a clearing.” Pointing towards a dull glow in the distance, Olivia said, “I don’t know what it is.”

After retrieving my gun from the car, I followed Olivia towards the clearing. We arrived to find Kyle standing outside of...well, I don’t know what it was. Whatever it was, it was shaped like an oval and was probably around 12 feet tall. A quick glance around the clearing showed some downed branches; whatever this thing was, it fell from the sky. Remembering why I was here, I turned my attention to Kyle. Going up to him, I grabbed him by the shirt collar and said, “I ought to beat the shit out of you.”

“Look man, I just wanted to be with your daughter.”

“Stop calling me man; you can call me Officer Sheppard.”

Before Kyle could respond, we were interrupted by the loud humming noise. The noise got louder until an opening into the object appeared behind us. Looking at the opening, Kyle said, “What the hell is going on here?”

“I don’t know; but I’m calling this in.” grabbing my radio, I was about to speak when I saw Kyle walking into the opening. “Don’t go inside, you idiot!”

But that didn’t stop him from entering. Olivia stood behind me and called out to him, “Kyle, come back!”

Suddenly there was a loud noise from inside the object; almost if something had slammed shut. After a moment, Olivia and I heard banging and what sounded like Kyle calling for help. Olivia started towards the opening, but I stopped her and said, “I’ll go and check it out.”

While Olivia stayed outside, I went through the opening and found myself in the strangest place I’d ever been in. There were several consoles and what looked like pipes, all leading to a hollow tube in the middle of the room – with Kyle inside.

As I walked over to the tube, I could hear Kyle’s muffled attempts to speak. “Get me out of here!”

“I’ll see what I can do.” Turning towards the tube, I said, “Next time how about you don’t go inside the strange object.”

I looked around the room for anything that would open the tube; but I there wasn’t anything useful that I could see. Looking at the consoles, I saw strange writing on them. What the hell is this place?

I continued looking around when I heard footsteps behind me. Turning around, I saw Olivia standing in front of the tube. “Kyle, are you alright?”

“I don’t know; just get me out of here!”

Suddenly the room filled with the sound of distant rumbling. Olivia and I could only watch as some strange gas started seeping into the chamber; followed by Kyle suddenly doubling over in pain.
11.title: The Chase Continues

111.content:
Olivia and I were momentarily confused as to what was going on. Suddenly my urge to beat the crap out of Kyle was replaced with the urge to get him out of the tube. While I looked around for anything to break the chamber, I turned to Olivia, “Honey, find something to break the glass. We have to get him out of there.”

But she didn’t move; instead, she just stood there in front of the tube, mesmerized but what was happening inside. Whatever the gas was that was entering the chamber, it was having a shocking effect on Kyle – it was changing him.

The first notable change that we saw was his skin changing from its normal white color to dark green. It wasn’t that the skin color was changing; the skin itself was also changing, as scales appeared on his body. Slamming a hand on the glass, struggling to fight the pain, Kyle said, “G-Get m-me out o-of here!”

I went back to searching for anything that I could use to break the chamber, but there was nothing that was useful. Meanwhile, Olivia was trying to keep Kyle’s spirits up, “Don’t worry babe, we’ll get you out of there!”

By this time almost 90% of Kyle’s body was covered in scales; with the changes now progressing to his face. The changes reminded me of those cheesy transformation scenes in old movies; as Kyle’s face slowly changed to resemble a canine snout. Another shocking change was the sudden appearance of a second, slightly smaller, set of eyes. I gave up searching as I was too engrossed by what was happening in the tube. By this point, Kyle’s screams of pain had turned into guttural, almost primal, growls.

Suddenly Kyle fell to his knees, as a series of cracking noises escaped the chamber. I watched in silent horror as Kyle’s legs bent themselves into an impossible position. While this was happening, Kyle’s feet and hands changed into paws; each with 3 sharp claws protruding from them. I quickly realized that, by this point, the Kyle we knew no longer existed – having been replaced by a large, scaly, quadrupedal creature. Unfortunately, the changes didn’t stop there; the creature’s back started to bubble up; as a series of sharp spines burst out of its skin.

What was left of the gas soon dissipated and we were left with a clear image of the creature inside the chamber. It looked to be about the size of a large bulldog; with a mouth full of razor-sharp teeth. It must’ve sensed that we were in the room because suddenly it started growling and clawing at the door.

Suddenly, without warning, the chamber door opened. Before I could stop her, Olivia stepped closer to the creature. Reaching her hand out, she said, “K-Kyle, are you in there?”

Olivia got an answer, just not the one she wanted, when the creature lunged at her. Before she knew what was happening, the creature had latched onto Olivia’s arm. Seeing my daughter in danger, I snapped back to reality and went to save her. Coming from behind the creature, I grabbed it and tried to pull it off of Olivia.

This only made it angry, as it released its grip on Olivia and turned its attention to me. In my attempt to dodge it, I caught one of its spines on my side. I was soon on the ground, lying on my back, trying to keep the creature from biting me. The room was suddenly filled with the sound of gunfire; followed by the creature’s pained cries.

Looking around I saw Olivia holding my gun, which I must’ve lost in the scuffle. In pain, but still able to fight, the creature lunged towards Olivia; only for her to finally kill it with a shot to the head.

Getting up from the floor, I made my way to Olivia; who collapsed to the floor in shock. I quickly removed my shirt and made a tourniquet around Olivia’s badly mangled arm. Once that was taken care of, we both just stared at the creature lying in a pool of blood on the floor – wondering what could have turned a human being into something like that.
111.title: A Horrifying Development

1111.content:
It seemed to take forever for the EMTs and backup to arrive on the scene. While the area was cordoned off, the EMTs tended to the injuries that Olivia and I had sustained. After examining the extensive damage to Olivia’s arm, the EMT said, “We’re going to need to get you to the hospital.” Looking at her, he said, “Who knows what kind of bacteria that...thing was carrying.”

“Why don’t you have a little respect?” turning to face him, I said, “That thing, as you called it, used to be my daughter’s boyfriend.”

“I’m sorry, I'll be more respectful sir.” Sighing, the EMT said, “We’re going to take her to the ER now, you should come along as well.”

“I’ll catch up later, I want to stay here for a few minutes.”

After the ambulance left the scene, I walked down to the clearing just as the creature was being removed from the object. Getting closer, I heard one of the coroners say, “What the hell is this thing?”

Another coroner, a young woman, said, “I don’t know; but whatever it is, it’s creepy.”

Looking at them both, I said, “As strange as it sounds, something inside that object turned my daughter’s boyfriend into that…thing.”

“Are you serious?”

With a sigh, I said, “Does this seem like something I’d make up?”

Suddenly the clearing was awash with light; as a series of helicopters suddenly appeared overhead. Before I could even ask myself what was going on, I saw half a dozen soldiers come out of the woods and into the clearing. They made their way over to where everyone was standing. One of the soldiers, an older man, said, “I’m Colonel Jackson; I have to ask that you all leave the area immediately.” Pausing, he said, “This is now a government operation, your presence is not required.”

I wanted to argue with the man but thought better of it. Turning to my guys, I said, “You heard the man, everyone leave the area.”

As I followed my people out of the clearing, I saw the helicopters landing as the troops cordoned off the area. But I couldn’t worry about that now, I had to get to the hospital to check on Olivia.
1111.title: The Aftermath

11111.content:
All I could think of during my drive to the hospital was a promise I'd made my wife before she died. I promised her that no matter what, I'd keep Olivia safe. As I drove into town, I feared tonight would be the time I failed that promise.

It was starting to rain when I arrived at the hospital. After parking my car, I ran into the ER and went right to the desk. "My daughter, Olivia Sheppard, was just brought in. Can you tell me what room she's in?"

The nurse behind the counter, a young man, went to work on the computer. After what seemed like an eternity, he said, "She's down the hall in Triage 1."

Making my way down the hall, I walked into the room to find a nurse applying some bandages to Olivia's arm. The nurse must've sensed I was in the room, because she looked up at me and said, "Sir, you can't be in here."

"The hell I can't, that's my daughter."

"My apologies sir." Standing up, she said, "I'm all finished here; the doctor will be in shortly."

Once the nurse left the room, closing the door behind her, I went over to Olivia's bedside. "Olivia, honey, it's dad."

They must've given her some powerful painkillers, because she seemed pretty out of it. Turning to me, slowly, she said, "Daddy?"

"It's alright honey, I'm here." Taking her uninjured hand in mine, I said, "I'm so happy you're alright."

"Wh-Where's Kyle?" Slurring a little bit, Olivia said, "I-Is he alright?"

In her current condition I didn't have the heart to tell her the truth. Sighing, I lied and said, "He's down the hall, sweetie."

At that moment the doctor walked into the room. "Hello, I'm Doctor Samson." Closing the door, he said, "I understand your daughter was attacked by an animal? Do you know what kind it was?"

"No, I don't." Pausing, not sure I should go into much detail, I said, "I've never seen anything like it in my life."

"Whatever the creature was, it caused massive damage to your daughter's arm. It's a miracle she didn't bleed out." Looking at the clipboard, he said, "Her bloodwork shows that she's fighting an infection; which we're combating with antibiotics. We should know in the morning if it's successful."

"Thank you doctor."

"You're welcome, sir." Getting up, he said, "In the meantime, we're going to move Olivia to a room in the ICU."

By that point Olivia had slipped into unconsciousness. I waited by her bedside until a nurse came to bring her upstairs. Before I left to follow, I squeezed her hand and kissed her forehead. "I love you, sweetie."
11111.title: At The Hospital

111111.content:
It came as no surprise to anyone that I didn’t get much, if any, sleep during the night. I spent most of my waking hours making sure Olivia was alright. There were a few times where her breathing got shallow that I feared she wasn’t breathing, but thankfully it was nothing to worry about.

I must’ve fallen asleep at some point, because I was startled awake when Dr. Samson entered the room. “Good morning, Mr. Sheppard; I trust you slept well last night?”

“Not exactly, doc.” Sighing, I got out of the chair, “How’s Olivia doing this morning?”

“She seems to be improving; her fever is down, which is a good thing.” Checking Olivia’s vitals, he said, “The lab still hasn’t been able to identify the bacteria samples taken from the wounds. It’s almost as if it’s not from this world.”

You have no idea, doc. “So is she out of the woods?”

“It’s too early to tell for sure; but I’d say her prognosis is pretty good.”

Suddenly the sound of footsteps filled the room; as half a dozen people ran past in the direction of the nurses’ station. Both Dr. Samson and I shared the same confused expression; looking at him, I said, “I wonder what’s going on.”

Leaving Olivia alone in the room, Dr. Samson and I made our way down the hall to the nurses’ station; where everyone was focused on a TV on the wall. Getting closer, I saw a young female reporter in some unfamiliar town. Behind her, I saw something similar to the object which changed Kyle. “What the hell is going on here?”

No one answered me; they were too focused on the TV. Turning my attention back, I listened to the reporter as she started to speak. “This is Elena Rojas; reporting live from downtown Hartland.” Pausing, I said, “As you can see behind me, the police have cordoned off a strange object which was dropped by an unknown flying craft only moments ago.”

She was briefly overpowered by the sound of what could only be the unknown craft; followed by several loud thumps in the distance. It didn’t take a genius to figure out that they were other objects hitting the ground.

“From what I’ve been able to gather; there are strange markings on the side of the object. No one has been able to decipher what they mean.”

Elena was suddenly interrupted by an all too familiar sound. I could only watch as gas started venting from holes in the side of the object. Those that were closest to the object were affected first; as they doubled over in pain. There was one big difference this time; the changes were much quicker. Within almost 20 seconds of exposure, those affected had been transformed into the same dog-like creature as Kyle. I also noticed some were transformed into something else; a tall reptilian-like bipedal creature.

At this point, everyone was screaming in fear; as both creatures started attacking. The dog-like creatures started attacking people indiscriminately; children, adults, all were targeted. Meanwhile, the bipedal creatures were grabbing anyone they could and pulling them towards the gas; creating more of the creatures.

Suddenly a strange craft landed next to the pod; the bipedal creatures started grabbing women and pulling them towards it. It was then that I noticed something – they were only grabbing pregnant women. What’s going on here?

Meanwhile, Elena had moved to safety behind a nearby car; recording the carnage around her. “I can’t explain what’s going on here; I’ve never seen anything...”

Elena was suddenly interrupted when one of the bipedal creatures grabbed her and started pulling her towards the gas. Her screams and kicking were ineffective; everyone in the room watched as the camera recorded her transformation into a dog-like creature. Within seconds the camera had stopped transmitting.

Everyone in the hall was frightened; wondering what we’d just seen. Before anyone could ask about what they’d just seen, we were interrupted by a distant rumbling. Whatever happened in Hartland, only 20 miles away, had just arrived here in Eastbourne.

While everyone, including Dr. Samson, panicked and fled the scene; I made my way back to Olivia's room, intent on keeping her safe no matter what. Arriving back in the room, I walked into find Olivia awake in bed. Looking at me, she said, "Daddy, what's going on?"

"I don't know, honey; but I'm going to find out." as a rumbling sound came from outside the building, I said, "Stay here and keep quite, alright?"

"O-Okay."

I quickly closed the door to Olivia's room and did what I could to barricade it. Going down the hall, I found myself standing in the elevator lobby; looking out a window overlooking the hospital campus. As it turned out, the rumbling noise was coming from a large alien craft landing across the green by the Maternity Ward.
111111.title: The Next Morning

1111111.content:
It took me a few minutes to get across the campus to the Maternity Ward; mainly because the hospital was on lockdown. Stopping around the corner from the entrance, I heard women screaming inside the ward. Taking a quick glance around the corner, I spotted some of the bipedal aliens forcibly removing the pregnant patients. I was surprised to find them also removing some of the males present in the ward; I figured they were probably the husbands or boyfriends of the expectant mothers.
Going back around the corner, I thought aloud to myself, “Why are these...things so interested in pregnant women?”

I was torn from my thoughts when I heard a man screaming. “No! Let her go!”

Peaking around the corner again, I saw a man slightly older than myself trying to remove a young teenage girl from the grip of one of the aliens. I realized I should do something to help, but there were too many of the creatures and I only had a pistol.

Suddenly one of the creatures came up and grabbed hold of the man; causing the young girl to start screaming, “Daddy!!”

I watched, helpless to do anything, as the creature pulled him back into one of the rooms; coming out before throwing a small canister into the room and closing the door. I wondered what was going on; when, seconds later, the door burst open and one of the dog-like creatures came out of the room.

Deciding to cut my losses, I made my way to a nearby stairwell and went upstairs; starting the trek back to the ICU. Stopping by a nearby window, I watched as the creatures led the captured people onto the ship. As the ship took off, I dreaded whatever fate was to befall those poor people.

It took some time, but I managed to get back to the ICU unscathed. Getting to Olivia’s room, I unbarricaded the door and opened it; barely missed the glass being thrown at my head. “Olivia it’s me!”

Olivia must’ve hidden in the bathroom; because she suddenly ran out of there and embraced me. “Daddy, what’s going on here?” looking up at me, she said, “W-What are these things?”

Holding her close, I said, “I don’t know, sweetie.”
1111111.title: Going to Investigate

11111111.content:
Olivia and I stayed in the room for what seemed like an eternity; listening as the fight went on in the streets. There was lots of screaming and gunfire. The few times that I risked taking a peek, I saw that the streets below were in absolute chaos; with cops and bystanders attacking the fighting the creatures. I saw several the dog-like creatures attacking people; leaving only bloody remains behind.

At one point Olivia joined me at the window; bursting into tears when she saw the dog-like creatures below. Collapsing to the floor, she said, “Daddy, I-I can’t stop thinking about Kyle.”

“I know, honey.” Closing the shade, I knelt down on the floor next to Olivia. Holding her, I said, “I may not have liked him that much, if at all, but no one deserved to go through that.”

I briefly considered telling Olivia about the soldiers cordoning off the clearing, but I decided against it. I could only imagine what they were doing to the deceased creature that had been Kyle. Wiping tears from her eyes, Olivia said, “W-What are we going to do now, Daddy?”

“I’m not sure, honey; there are too many of those things out there.” Sighing, I said, “We wouldn’t make it 20 feet before we were killed, or worse...”

Olivia didn’t need to ask what I meant; chances were good that if we tried to escape, we’d end up being turned into one of those creatures down there. Leaning against my shoulder, she closed her eyes and tried to ignore the sounds outside.

We stayed like that for a while; jumping occasionally when a loud noise outside startled us. After what I figured was about an hour, we suddenly heard a noise from out in the hallway. Gesturing for Olivia to be quite, I quietly made my way to the door. Opening it a crack, I looked out the door to see ______.
11111111.title: Hiding Out

111111111.content:
Looking out from the door, I saw about a dozen panicked people entering the ward. Stepping out of the room, my hand on my gun, I said, “Stop right there!”

“Please, you’ve got help us!” looking at me, a panicked girl in her mid-20s said, “Those things are everywhere!”

As I looked around the room at the panicked people, I was torn between my oath as a cop and wanting to keep Olivia safe. The people were in various states of panic; some of them wounded, one of them was missing the lower portion of his right arm. Before I could make a decision, Olivia came out of the room.

Seeing the people, she said, “Daddy, what’s going on?”

“These people were fleeing from those things outside.”

“Shouldn’t we be helping them?” standing next to me, a concerned look on her face, Olivia said, “I mean some of them look really messed up.”

“Right now my biggest concern is keeping you safe.” Pulling Olivia aside, I said, “I can’t do that if I’m keeping 12 other people safe.”

“You’ll have to figure something out because I’m helping them.” Grabbing some bandages from a nearby shelf, Olivia looked at me and said, “If Mom saw you right now, she’d be so disappointed.”

I watched as Olivia went to work; handing out bandages and helping out where she could. Her words echoed in my head; and she was right, Amy would be disappointed in me. Following in Olivia’s footsteps, I grabbed some bandages and went to work on the man missing his arm.

*****************************


As I feared, Olivia ended up overexerting herself; leading to her collapsing on the floor about 30 minutes after the survivors arrived. It turned out that one of the survivors was a nurse from another hospital, so she stayed with Olivia while I continued working with the survivors.

Despite my best efforts, the man with the arm injury didn’t survive; I guess he just lost too much blood. Looking at the woman cradling his body, I said, “I’m sorry for your loss.”

“I-I didn’t even know him before today.” Wiping tears from her eyes, she said, “H-He saved me from one of those creatures, the ones with the 4 eyes. That thing...it used to be my girlfriend.”

I wasn’t sure what to do at this moment, but my instincts told me to take the woman’s hands. “You shouldn’t blame yourself for this.”

“H-He died trying to save me.” Looking at me, the woman said, “You know the worst part of this whole thing? I wouldn’t have been in this town had my girlfriend’s car not gotten a flat tire.”

I did my best to console the woman, but she was in too much shock. After asking a young boy to stay with her, I walked down the hall to Olivia’s room. Seeing the nurse standing by her bedside, I said, “Is she alright?”

“I can’t tell for sure; her temperature is through the roof.” Gesturing to Olivia’s arm, she said, “I can only assume she was attacked by one of those creatures out there?”

“She and her boyfriend encountered one of the pods by the dam last night.” Sighing, I said, “The gas changed him into one of the
4-eyed creatures, and...it subsequently attacked her.”

“Without knowing the treatments she was on, I’m not sure what I’m supposed to do.”

“The doctors were giving her antibiotics before they ran off.” Walking to Olivia’s bed, I said, “They weren’t sure what kind of bacteria was in her system, but they thought antibiotics might do the trick.”

“I’ll see if I can’t find her medical file in the mess out there.” Looking at me, the nurse said, “I promise I’ll do what I can to keep her alive.”

"Thank you..."

"Margo, Margo Johnson."

"Thank you, Margo." smiling, I said, "My name's Eric and this is my daughter Olivia."

"It's nice to meet you both; although I do wish it was under better circumstances."

"You and me both."
111111111.title: Frightened Civilians

1111111111.content:
The fighting outside continued for another couple hours until it finally stopped; a few of us went to see what happened. From my vantage point on the 4th floor, looking down the street, I saw burning vehicles and craters in the road. I wondered what could’ve caused the craters when I remembered hearing the occasional explosion.

I saw bodies all over the road; mostly humans, but some were the creatures. I found myself wondering what those people were thinking, in their last moments, as they were transformed against their will. Pushing those thoughts from my head, I made my way back to the ICU; which we’d managed to barricade using some shelves and gurneys.

Once back inside the ward, I walked towards two of the other scouts; a teenage boy and a man slightly older than me. “Did you guys see anything out there?”

“I saw some of those four-legged things chewing on what I could assume was once a human body.” Shuddering, the young boy said, “Other than that, I didn’t see anything.”

“I saw pillars of smoke all over town, and a few of those alien ships in the distance.” Looking at me, the man said, “I’d really like to know what’s going on here; is another country attacking us?”

“I somehow doubt this is the work of another country.” Sighing, I said, “Based on what I saw in the pod last night, I think we’re dealing with an alien species.”

“Aliens?” scoffing, the man said, “Surely you’re joking.”

“How else would you explain the strange creatures out there?” pausing, I said, “I don’t know about you, but I’ve never seen a four-eyed animal before.”

“It just seems so impossible.”

Before I could speak, we were interrupted by the return of the 4th scout. As we went to let him through the barricade, I saw that he wasn’t alone – he had the corpse of one of the bipedal creatures.

********************


After getting the children into another room, we managed to drag the corpse into an empty nearby room. Margo walked into the room, stopping in the doorway when she saw the creature lying on the bed. “What’s that doing here?”

“I found it searching through the Pediatrics wing; probably looking for survivors.” Gesturing to the scratches on his arms, the man said, “It took some effort to kill it, but I managed to get it done.”

“Can we please stop referring to this as it?” pausing, I said, “Need I remind you, this thing used to be a human being?”

“I don’t like this any more than you do, Eric.” Sighing, the older man said, “But that...thing on the table isn’t human anymore. We can’t think of it that way anymore.”

“Okay fine; just be careful about how you talk about them.” Sighing, I said, “There’s a young woman out there, Grace, whose girlfriend was turned into one of the dog-things; just like my daughter’s boyfriend last night.”

While everyone talked amongst themselves, I decided to get a closer look at the creature lying before me. It looked to be around 6’5” tall and covered in the same scales that I’d seen on the dog-things. The face was reminded me of the Gorn from Star Trek; the only noticeable difference that I saw being a row of spiked horns going up between the eyes from the nose. The jaw looked like someone had squished together an alligator jaw; I saw several sharp teeth sticking out.

As I looked further down the creature’s body, I saw its hands had sharp claws instead of fingers; one could only assume the same could be said for the feet. By that point, everyone had stopped talking and turned their attention to Margo. Having returned with a tray of instruments, she said, “If we’re to learn anything about these things, I’ll have to perform an autopsy.”
1111111111.title: Later On

11111111111.content:
Almost two hours passed before Margo walked out of the room; her hands and arms covered in a green liquid that I could only imagine was blood. Removing her gloves, she gestured for me to follow her into another room.

Once the two of us alone, I turned to Margo and said, “What did the autopsy show?”

“Whatever that...thing is, it’s not like anything here on Earth.” Sighing, Margo said, “Its lungs were twice the size of a human's and its heart had 6 chambers instead of 4.”

“Unfortunately biology wasn’t my strong suit in High School.” Looking at Margo, I said, “What does that all mean?”

“That creature is built for endurance; I wouldn’t be surprised if it could go for days without rest.” Looking at the two of us, leaning against the counter, Margo said, “I’m inclined to agree with your hypothesis; that this thing might be an alien.”

Turning away from Margo, I stared at the wall for a moment. Turning around again, I said, “Try to remember that thing used to be human.” Sighing, I said, “Whatever it is now, it used to have a family and friends. It used to be just like us.”

“I can tell you right now, it wasn’t human when it died.” Running a hand through her hair, Margo said, “Whatever that gas is, it’s able to completely rewrite an individual’s DNA in a matter of seconds.”

“Olivia was bitten by one of those creatures; what if that bacteria in her system is trying to transform her?”

“I’ve seen nothing to indicate that would happen.” Sighing, Margo said, “I compared a sample of Olivia’s blood to that of the creature; aside from a high white blood cell count, Olivia’s blood cells are still human.”

“So this gas is turning people into these creatures.” Pausing, I said, “What can we do to stop it?”

“I’m not sure; I don’t know if there’s any way to prevent the gas from affecting someone.”

As if on cue, Margo and I were interrupted by a commotion outside in the hall. Both of us walked outside to find a boy, no older than 17, holding one of the gas grenades I’d seen earlier. “Hey check this out, I found it out in the hallway.” Tossing it up and down, the boy said, “I think it might be a dud.”

Wondering to myself how stupid a kid would have to be in order to play with something like that, I started walking towards him. “Kid, you have to get rid of…”

Before I could finish my sentence, the grenade started making a noise. Whatever the kid had done, he must’ve accidently activated it. I hated doing it, but I didn’t want to risk the lives of everyone in the room. So I made the painful choice of shoving the kid, and the grenade, into the makeshift autopsy room.

I closed the door just as the gas was released; causing the kid to start banging on the door, begging to be let out. Unfortunately, there was nothing I could do; as the changes had already started – first his face started changing and the horns started growing from his nasal ridge.

Seconds later the boy was gone; his screams transformed into a mixture of hisses and growls. Everyone present bowed their heads in sorrow; mourning the loss of the young man.
11111111111.title: Post-Autopsy

111111111111.content:
The creature inside the room had been pounding on the door for the last few minutes. It didn’t take a genius to know the door wasn’t going to hold for long. While everyone was still mourning the loss of the young man, I realized it wasn’t safe for us to stay here any longer.

“Listen up everyone; we need to leave now; before that door fails.”

I wasn’t surprised when no one moved a muscle; many of them seemingly frozen in fear. Margo was the only one who seemed to acknowledge what I was staying. “Eric’s right, we have to leave now or that thing will kill us all once it’s free.”

“Where are we supposed to go?” looking at me, a middle-aged woman said, “Those things are everywhere.”

“I don’t know where we can go.” Sighing, realizing that was a problem with my plan, I said, “I just know we can’t stay here.”

“Why should we listen to you?”

Looking at the man who’d spoken, a man around my age holding two young children, I said, “I’m a Police officer sir, believe me when I say we need to go now.”

No one moved an inch until the creature managed to shatter the small window in the door. That was enough to get everyone moving. While a few of the men worked to get the barricade down, Margo and I made our way to Olivia’s room. She must’ve woken up from the commotion because she was lying in bed looking at us. “What’s going on out there?”

“We have to go, honey.” Moving towards the bed, I said, “One of the young men accidentally activated a grenade; he was turned into one of the creatures and it’ll break through the door very soon.”

While I went to make sure the coast was clear, Margo helped support Olivia as they left the room. Rounding the corner, I saw everyone else had already left the area. As we made our way past the autopsy room, the door burst open and the creature came out. It quickly made its way towards Margo and Olivia; I tried to stop it but only ended up being slammed into a nearby wall.

The force of the impact stunned me, and I was worried I may have broken something. I could only watch as the creature continued advancing towards them. Unable to do anything, I watched helplessly as the creature grabbed Margo and threw her into the nurses' station. Worried that Margo was injured, I tried to find something to attack the creature with.

Ignoring Olivia, the creature advanced towards Margo’s prone form. Just as the creature was about to strike, I heard several gunshots; followed by the creature collapsing to the ground right in front of Margo. Looking around for the source of the gunfire, I saw Olivia holding my gun; which I must’ve lost when I was thrown.

Once she was satisfied the creature was dead, Olivia lowered the gun and ran over to me. “Daddy, are you alright?”

“I’m fine, honey.” I was lying; I was actually in a fair amount of pain. As I stood up, with Olivia’s help, I said, “Go check on Margo; I think she’s hurt.”

“I-I’m fine.”

Olivia and I both turned to find Margo slowly getting to her feet. Looking at her, shocked, I said, “Are you sure? That was a pretty strong throw.”

“I’m sure.” Groaning, Margo said, “I’ll be fine in a couple of hours.”

I wasn't sure I bought Margo's statement; it seemed a little strange that she was practically fine after sustaining that kind of injury. I didn't have time to dwell on it; as several of the survivors came running into the room. After seeing the state we were in, they helped us walk out of the room. We met up with everyone else by the stairs. As we slowly made our way downstairs, I could hear Margo say, “I don’t think we’ve been properly introduced; my name is Margo Sullivan.”

I turned around to see Olivia shaking Margo’s outstretched hand. “It’s nice to meet you, I’m Olivia Sheppard.”

Upon reaching the bottom floor, we exited into the lobby to find _____.
111111111111.title: Making Our Escape

1111111111111.content:
As soon as we exited the stairwell, we were stopped by a dozen or so police officers. Some of them were from neighboring towns, but a few of them I recognized. One of the unfamiliar cops pointed his gun at us; yelling, “Stop right there!”

Everyone in the group, including myself, started to worry about what was going to happen next. Did we just escape one of those creatures to be killed by a trigger happy officer? Thankfully, before anything happened, a fellow officer stepped and lowered the gun. “Lower that weapon, Corporal! Can’t you see these are just frightened civilians?”

I quickly spotted one of my coworkers, Theo Gagnon, in the crowd. Hobbling over to him, I said, “Theo, what’s going on here?”

“Thank god you’re alright, Eric; no one’s heard from you since last night.” Hugging me, Theo said, “How’s Olivia, is she alright?”

Turning to my right, I found Olivia being helped onto a gurney. Looking back at Theo, I said, “Other than some unusual bacterial infection, she’s doing fine.”

“I’m glad to hear that.” turning glum, Theo said, “We...We lost almost half the department; most of them were killed in the chaos, but a few of them were transformed into those creatures.”

“I guess that explains the cops from other towns.” Sighing, I said, “What’s the plan here?”

“We’ve got some buses running; we’re taking everyone we can find and taking them to the prison.”

“The prison?” confused, I said, “Why are we taking them there for god’s sake?”

“It’s the most secure place in the area.” Sighing, Theo said, “Look, I know it’s not ideal; but it’s our only option right now.”

After Theo and I finished talking, I made my way over to Olivia and Margo. Holding Olivia’s hand in her own, Margo looked at me and said, “Olivia saved my life, Eric.”

“That’s my baby girl; always willing to help others, even at her own expense.” Looking at Margo, I said, “Are you certain that you’re alright?”

“I assure you, I’m fine.” Sighing, Margo said, “I’m going to be sore for a while, but I’m fine.”

Suddenly we were interrupted by one of the other cops starting to talk. “Okay folks, we have some buses and one ambulance available to move everyone out of here.” Pausing, he said, “Please don’t shove; there’s room enough for everyone.”

A few minutes passed and almost everyone was situated. After checking on one of the buses, I made my way to the ambulance where I found Margo standing by the back door. I watched as she climbed up on the bumper and said, “There’s room for 4 more people in here; I repeat, there’s room for 4 more.”

I had to chuckle a little bit; because despite saying there were 4 spots remaining, I saw Margo holding up 5 fingers. I wanted to question it but realized it wasn’t important. Walking over to her, I said, “Where’s Olivia?”

“She’s already inside.” Looking at me, Margo said, “I reserved a spot for you; I suggest you take it.”

I quickly agreed; having no intention of leaving Olivia by herself. After helping a few more passengers into the ambulance, including the poor woman who’d lost her girlfriend, I went to close everything up. It was only then that I realize Margo wasn’t anywhere to be seen. “Margo!”

After searching for a few moments, I spotted Margo walking out from behind a nearby dumpster; putting something into her pocket as she walked towards me. “Sorry, I-I needed to check something.”

“Don’t run off like that; we could’ve left without you.”

“Well then, thank you for waiting for me.”

With that, Margo and I climbed into the ambulance. The convoy of vehicles departed a moment later; heading out of town with about 3 dozen people in tow.
1111111111111.title: A Rescue

11111111111111.content:
The ride to the prison would normally take only 15 minutes; but with many of the streets blocked or impassable, it would probably end up taking longer. Almost 30 minutes had passed since we left the hospital, and we’d only just reached the outskirts of town.

After checking in with the lead vehicle, I made my way to the back of the ambulance to check on everyone. Seeing Margo checking on Olivia’s vitals, I said, “How’s my little girl doing?”

“She seems to be doing a little better.” Taking the stethoscope out of her ears, Margo said, “With an infection like this, her chances of survival depend on when the treatment was started.”

“I thought you didn’t know what kind of bacteria it was?” confused, I said, “How could you possibly know the course of treatment for an infection like that?”

Margo must’ve realized I’d caught her on something; because she quickly said, “I, uh, I mean...with any kind of bacterial infection, it’s always best to start treatment as soon as possible.”

Taking a seat along the wall, careful not to wake the sleeping child next to me, I turned to Margo and said, “You’ve been so helpful today; first with Olivia and then the autopsy.” Pausing, I said, “I realize that I don’t know anything about you.”

“There’s nothing much to tell, really.” Sitting down, Margo said, “I was born in Seattle; after I got my nursing degree, I decided that
I wanted to work in a small-town hospital. So I moved to Hartland about a month ago.”

“What brought you here all the way from Hartland?”

“I was on a blind date; one of my coworkers set me up with her sister.” Seeing the surprised look on my face, Margo said, “Big surprise, the cute nurse is a lesbian.”

“Sorry, I didn’t mean to be disrespectful.” Pausing, I said, “The date must not have gone very well; since you don’t seem too worried about her.”

“It started out well; I mean she was just as attractive as her sister made her out to be.” With a chuckle, Margo said, “I don’t know what happened; it’s just...we didn’t click.”

“For what it’s worth, I’m sorry the date didn’t go well.”

“I’m sure I’ll find someone eventually.” Smiling, Margo said, “After all, the ocean is full of fish; right?”

“I’m sorry, what?”

“I mean there’s probably a girl out there for me, right?”

“Oh, that’s what you meant.” Chuckling, I said, “The phrase is actually – there’s plenty of fish in the sea.”

“Oh, my mistake.” Pausing, Margo said, “With all that’s happened, I guess I got a little confused.”

Just then, without warning, the ambulance came to a sudden stop. Going back up to the front, I looked at the driver and said,
“What’s going on?”

“I’m not sure, everyone just stopped.”

“I guess I’ll go take a look then.” Turning back to Margo, I said, “Keep an eye on everyone while I’m gone.”

“Understood.”

Climbing out of the ambulance, I walked past a number of people standing around; all of them wondering what was going on. Eventually, I made my way to the front of the group; where I found a bunch of cops staring at ______.
11111111111111.title: On the Road

111111111111111.content:
The cops and I stared at where the bridge should have been, but there was nothing there anymore. I was in disbelief since I’d just driven over the bridge on the way to the hospital. I snapped back to reality when I felt someone’s hand on my shoulder.
Turning around, I saw Theo standing with another man wearing a Hartland PD uniform. “Detective Eric Sheppard, this is Lieutenant Troy Dillon; Hartland PD.”

After shaking his hand, Captain Dillon said, “I understand your daughter was injured by one of those creatures last night. I certainly hope she’s doing okay.”

“She’s fighting some sort of bacterial infection, but the nurse that’s with her is doing everything she can.”

“I will keep your daughter in my thoughts, Detective.” Sighing, Dillon said, “Right now our biggest concern is getting these civilians to the prison.”

Standing in front of Dillon and me, Theo said, “The only other road to the prison goes through the hills; it’ll add another 40 minutes to the drive.”

“I don’t see that we have much choice; we’re sitting ducks here if those ships find us.”

“I agree with Dillon; we don’t have...”

I was suddenly interrupted when, from the back of the convoy, I heard Margo yell, “ERIC!”

Without hesitation, I ran to the back of the convoy; finding the occupants of the ambulance standing on the side of the road.
Going around to the back, I saw Olivia seizing on the gurney. “What happened?”

“I’m not sure; one minute we were talking and the next she started seizing.”

Climbing into the ambulance, with Olivia still seizing, I said, “What can we do?”

“We can’t do anything until the seizing stops.” Looking at me, Margo said, “I can’t know for certain, but I’m pretty sure her infection is getting worse.”

Sitting back against the seat, I was suddenly faced with the very real possibility that I might lose my daughter. I may not be her biological father, but I was in the delivery room when she was born. I knew from the first moment I held her in my arms that I was going to do everything I could to keep her safe. Turning to Margo, I said, “You have to do something, Margo; Olivia...she’s all I have left.”

Retrieving a large vial, full of a pale blue liquid, Margo said, “I promise, Eric, that I’ll do everything I can to keep her alive.”

Once the seizing finally stopped, I watched Margo injected the blue liquid into Olivia’s arm; causing the veins in her arm to temporally turn light blue. I’d never seen medication do anything like that, but so far Margo hadn’t done anything to make me question my faith in her. “I have faith in you Margo; do what you have to.”

After helping everyone into the ambulance, I went to get into the passenger seat. As I climbed in, I saw Margo staring into the sky; and I thought I heard her say something like “please hurry.”

*************************


It took some time to get all the vehicles turned around, but eventually, we were back on the road again. I was sitting in the passenger seat of the ambulance, trying to keep my mind off of Olivia, when suddenly there was a bright green flash and the bus in front of us exploded.
111111111111111.title: A Destroyed Bridge

1111111111111111.content:
The entire convoy came to a screeching halt; but not before one bus rear-ended another. I looked through the windshield just as an alien craft flew by. I quickly realized it had fired something that destroyed the bus.

As it flew out of sight, I climbed out of the ambulance and made my way to the wreckage. A quick glance at the wreckage told me there were no survivors; as best I could recall, I think there had been six children riding on this one bus.

I could see some people getting out of the other buses; many of them crying because of what just happened. Walking over to them, I said, “Folks, you have to get back in the buses right now.”

“Why bother?” A woman slightly older than me, appearing to be in shock, said, “Those things clearly have technology that we don’t; how can we possibly survive this?”

“I understand that you have misgivings; but if we stay here, we’re most certainly going to die.”

Despite my best efforts, the woman had managed to rile up a few surrounding people. Before I could do anything, they were all starting to panic. Everyone suddenly went quiet when a series of loud noises surrounded us. This caused everyone, including me, to become momentarily concerned.

The woman and some of the people around her started moving away from the convoy. “W-We can’t stay here!”

At that point, Theo and the other cops had arrived and tried their best to mediate the situation. But they weren’t having any of it; before anyone could stop them, a group of six people ran off into the woods in fright.

While 3 cops stayed behind, armed with shotguns, I ran off after Theo as he and 2 other cops tried to stop the runners. I caught up to the group in a clearing; with Theo and the others trying to calm everyone down. I started towards them when I spotted, out of the corner of my eye, 5 of the bipedal aliens coming towards them.

Before I could anything to warn them, the creatures threw grenades into the crowd. However, this time, instead of transforming everyone; they just knocked them out. Desperate to save the group, I started shooting; injuring one of the creatures. When it started chasing after me, I realized my mistake. Shit!

I started running back towards the road; looking back long enough to see the ship landing in the clearing, as the remaining creatures loaded the unconscious bodies into the ship. Turning my attention back to running, I made my way back to the road to find the remaining cops pointing their guns in my direction. I quickly realized they were aiming at the creature and not me.

It didn’t take much to bring the creature down. As I collapsed to the ground, exhausted, I wondered what horrible fate would soon befall those who were captured.
1111111111111111.title: Chaos

11111111111111111.content:
I was surprised when the aliens didn’t come after us after landing in the clearing. After getting the survivors back onto the buses, we quickly left the area. I sat in the back of the ambulance while Margo was bandaging up some wounds I’d sustained while running from the creature.

Looking up at me as she wrapped my arm, Margo said, “Penny for your thoughts?”

“I’m just thinking about the people those things captured.” Sighing, I said, “What use could those things possibly have for them?”

“I wouldn’t dwell on it, Eric.” Grabbing some bandages for my head, Margo said, “I’d just focus on the living, and we can worry about the dead at another time.”

“We don’t know if they’re dead, Margo.” Looking at her, I said, “We have to think positively; hopefully we can go rescue them. That’s what I hope would happen if I were them.”

Turning her attention to a pack of antiseptic wipes, without looking at me, Margo said, “If I were one of them, I’d want to die with dignity.”

I stared at Margo for a moment; unsure of what to think about her. She’d been nothing but helpful taking care of Olivia, but I couldn’t help but wonder if she was hiding something. “Are you okay, Margo? You seem a little...off.”

“I’m fine,” looking at me, sighing, she said, “I’m just...today’s been a hard day.”

“I suppose we’re all entitled to respond differently to situations like this.”

“I suppose you’re right.” After placing the bandage on my forehead, Margo said, “That’s it; you’re all patched up.”

“Thanks; I promise to be more careful next time.”

“That’s all I ask.” Glancing to Olivia, who’d been unconscious since the seizures, Margo said, “I’m already taking care of one
Sheppard, I don’t want to be taking care of another one.”

It wasn’t long before the ambulance stopped again. Fearing another obstacle, I went up front expecting to the creatures; instead, I was pleasantly surprised to see the prison’s front gate.
11111111111111111.title: Continuing to the Prison

111111111111111111.content:
As a police officer, I never enjoyed having to visit the prison. But after the events of today, I had a feeling that would change. Poking her head into the cab, Margo said, “What’s going on? Are we under attack again?”

“No, we’re at the prison.” Sighing, I said, “We’re safe; at least for the time being.”

“The timing couldn’t be better; I need to get Olivia and the rest of the injured to the infirmary.”

The gates slowly started to open at that point; letting the vehicles enter the compound. As we drove through, I saw at least 4 officers on each of the nearby guard towers; each armed with rifles. I also 3 other buses parked in the far corner of the compound; realizing we must not have been the first group.

Once everything came to a stop, I climbed out of the ambulance and saw a familiar face approaching me – Chief Tom Hertle; my boss. After hugging me, he said, “I’m glad to see you got here in one piece.” Smiling, he said, “I’ve sent out four groups to search for survivors; only two of them have come back so far.”

“Not everyone in our group made it, Chief.” Sighing, I said, “One of those alien ships destroyed a bus carrying 6 children.”

Looking around, Chief Hertle said, “Where’s Theo? I had him in charge of this group.”

“After the bus was destroyed, several survivors panicked and ran into the woods. Theo and 2 cops ran after them; only to be surrounded by the creatures.” Taking a deep breath, I said, “The entire group was captured; I don’t know for what purpose.”

Chief Hertle’s face turned sullen when I said that; Theo and he had been drinking buddies. “Let’s get everyone settled; then we can figure out where our people were taken and get them back.”

Just then Margo came over; with the injured behind her. Without wasting time, she looked at Chief Hertle and said, “I need you to take me to your infirmary; I have injured here that need treatment.”

Chief Hertle ordered a nearby officer to bring Margo to the infirmary; I watched as a Prison Guard followed behind them. “What’s with the escort, Chief?”

“Some of the prisons aren’t being very cooperative.” Sighing, Chief said, “I hope they come to their senses soon; because I have a feeling we’re all going to be here for a while.”

I had wondered about that myself; whether the civilians would be able to live peacefully with the prisoners. I didn’t want to focus on that now; so after saying goodbye to Chief Hertle, I ran to catch up with Margo and the injured.
111111111111111111.title: The Prison

1111111111111111111.content:
I quickly realized why the escort had been necessary; as the path to the infirmary took me through one of the cell blocks. Walking through, I was bombarded with screams from the inmates.

When I eventually got to the infirmary, which was rudimentary at best, I that Margo had things pretty much under control. There didn’t seem to be any doctors around but I did see a few orderlies mingling amongst the injured.

Walking through the room, I entered the ICU to find Margo standing by Olivia’s bedside. I watched as she injected another vial of the strange blue liquid into Olivia’s arm; this time causing her skin to take on a slight blue tint. Before I could ask what the liquid was, I felt something run into my leg.

Looking down, I saw a young boy no older than 6 years old. “Hey mister, have you seen my grandparents?”

“I’m sorry, but I don’t think so.”

A sad look appeared on the boy’s face; he must’ve been separated from his grandparents. My answer clearly wasn’t the one he wanted. “Oh, o-okay.”

Before I could say anything else, Margo walked over with a toy truck in her hands. Handing it to the boy, she said, “David, sweetie, why don’t you go play in the corner for a little while.”

Without saying a word, David walked over to the far corner and started playing with the toy truck. Turning my attention to Margo, I said, “Are you doubling as a babysitter now?”

“It sure feels like that.” Leading me into another room, Margo said, “He was with the first group that arrived; he got separated from his grandparents in the initial chaos.”

I felt terrible when Margo said that; in all likelihood, David’s grandparents were probably dead. The situation brought back memories from when I had to tell Olivia that her mom had been killed in a car accident. “You realize he'll have to find out eventually, right?”

“I know; just not right now.” Peeking around the corner, looking at David, Margo said, “He’s just a little kid; he’s not ready yet.”

“Were any of us ready for this?”

“That’s a fair point.” Checking a clock on the wall, Margo said, “It’s getting pretty late; how about you go get some rest. I’ll tell you if Olivia’s condition changes.”

“If it’s all the same, I’d like to stay close.”

“I completely understand.”

As Margo turned to walk away, I grabbed her by the arm and pulled her back. Before she could say anything, I embraced her.
“Thank you, Margo.”

After getting over her initial shock, Margo reciprocated the hug and said, “You’re welcome, Eric.”

Taking a seat next to Olivia's bed, I watched as Margo went over to David. I couldn't hear what she said, but the two of them walked out of the room.
1111111111111111111.title: The Infirmary

11111111111111111111.content:
I didn’t get much sleep that night; choosing to stay with Olivia. As the night progressed, I started to notice some strange changes happening to Olivia; her skin was getting progressively bluer, while I noticed something was happening to her hands and feet as well – it was almost as if some of her fingers and toes were dissolving. I started to question whether my faith in Margo had been misplaced; what if she was harming Olivia instead of helping her.

It must’ve been just after midnight when I started to doze off; only to be awakened when I heard Olivia start to stir. Looking at her, I watched as she slowly opened her eyes and turned to me. “Daddy?”

“Olivia!” getting up, I immediately took her hand in mine. “Sweetie, how are you feeling?”

“I-I’m scared, Daddy.” Looking at me, fear in her eyes, she said, “Am I going to die?”

“Of course not, sweetie.” Looking at her, trying to keep stay positive, I said, “Margo says you’re doing just fine; you’ll be back on your feet in a few days.”

“I’m sorry, Daddy.” Tearing up, Olivia said, “I’m sorry I was such a lousy daughter.”

“Don’t you talk like that, Olivia.” Squeezing her hand, I said, “You’re the best daughter in the world; I’m lucky to be your father.”

“When I see Mom, I’ll...”

When Olivia suddenly slipped into unconsciousness, I feared the worst. “N-No no, Olivia!” after several attempts to wake her failed, I started panicking, “MARGO!!”

Margo must’ve been nearby because she was at Olivia’s side within seconds. “What’s wrong?”

“Sh-She was talking and suddenly lost consciousness.” Worried, I said, “Is she...”

Checking Olivia’s vitals, Margo said, “She’s not dead, but she will be soon if we don’t hurry.” Retrieving another vial, Margo said, “Another dose of this should stabilize her for the time being.”

Before Margo could inject Olivia, I grabbed her hand and said, “I need you to tell me what the stuff is.”

“Eric, we don’t have time to discuss this.” Trying to inject Olivia, Margo said, “I have to inject Olivia now!”

“I won’t let you inject her until you tell me what’s going on.” Shoving Margo into the wall, I gestured to the changes to Olivia’s body.
“Why is that stuff turning her skin blue? Why does it look like her fingers and toes are changing?”

“I-I can’t...”

“I put my faith in you to save my little girl; so help me if you’re...”

I wasn’t able to finish my sentence; because I was suddenly overwhelmed by the sound of something akin to a jet engine. As the sound got closer, the room lit up as lights poured through the windows. Forgetting about Margo for a moment, I made my way to the exercise yard just as a strange ship was landing there. Fearing that it was the creatures, I quickly raised my weapon; as did all the officers present.

Once the craft landed, and the searchlights had been pointed at it, I got my first glimpse of it. I could tell that it wasn’t one of the creature’s ships, but it was still alien. It almost resembled a manta ray in overall shape; with a raised section in the middle. I watched as a door in the back opened, and several figures came out.

Making my way to the back, I saw the newcomers for the first time; and they were most certainly not the creatures who attacked us. These beings were shorter, almost about the height of the average human, and they had dark blue skin. Before anyone could stop them, one of the aliens stepped forward and said, “Lower your weapons; we mean you no harm.”
11111111111111111111.title: During the Night

111111111111111111111.content:
I suppose I shouldn’t have been surprised to hear the alien speaking perfect English; especially after what I’ve been through today. With the guards pointing their weapons at the aliens, Chief Hertle stepped forward until he was standing only a few feet from the alien craft. “You’ll have to forgive me; but how do we know you’re not the aliens who attacked us?”

I watched as one of the other aliens stepped forward, as if to say something; only to be stopped by the tallest one. Turning back to Chief Hertle, he said, “I believe you’ll have to, what is the saying, take a leap of faith.”

Chief Hertle did nothing for a moment; clearly thinking over his options. After a moment, he signaled for the guards to lower their weapons. “Don’t make me regret this, sir.”

I was quickly becoming aware of a crowd forming in the yard; as word of the ship must’ve been spreading. I could hear some people murmuring; wondering if these aliens were the enemy. Walking towards Chief Hertle, I said, “Chief; I think we should take this inside. We’re starting to get a crowd here.”

“Chief?” turning to Hertle, the alien said, “Perhaps I’m mistaken, but I thought your species moved past tribalism centuries ago.”

I started wondering how the aliens knew so much about us. If Chief Hertle shared my concerns, he didn’t show it. With a smile, he said, “It’s my rank; I’m Chief of Police.”

“I understand now.” Looking out at the crowd, the alien said, “I am in agreement with your subordinate; it would be wise to move inside.”

While several guards stayed behind to disperse the crowd and watch the ship, the rest of them followed us into the prison. As we made our way to the Warden’s office, avoiding the occupied areas, I took the opportunity to get a good look at the aliens.

The three of them varied in appearance and were approximately 5’8 to around 6’3” in height. I was surprised to see that they only had fingers on each hand. I noticed their skulls were elongated; with two of them having blunt edges and the third having more rounded edges. I also noticed a distinct lack of hair on their heads.

Looking closer at their skulls, I wondered why their shapes were different. That was until I noticed the shortest of the three had breasts – I quickly realized it must’ve been a gender difference in their species. Moving past that, I got a good look at their clothes as well – pretty similar to jogging suits in appearance; they appeared to be form-fitting.

Once we arrived at the Warden’s office; Chief Hertle and I went inside with the aliens while the guards waited outside. We all stood around the desk in the middle of the room. Once the door was closed, the lead alien said, “I suppose now would be a good time for introductions. My name is Borza Trogrik, Senior Overseer.” Gesturing to his associates, he said, “These are my associates; my apprentice, Phiemu Crican and my pilot Dhelo Ros’ath. We are Maltorians.”

After Chief Hertle introduced me, he said, “What brings you to Earth, Mr. Trogrik?”

“Please call me Borza.” Pausing, Borza said, “We received word that your world had been invaded by the Creelaxians. We are here to help defeat them.”

“What can you tell us about these Creelaxians?”

“Only that they’re a menace to all life in the galaxy.” The female alien, Dhelo, stepped forward and said, “They invaded our world 15 years ago; leaving only the 1500 survivors aboard our ship.”

I couldn’t help but feel sympathy for these people; with only 1500 of their kind left. “I’m truly sorry to hear that.” Sighing, I said, “With your help, hopefully, we can prevent that from happening here.”

Turning to Dhelo, Borza said, “Return to the shuttle and inform the command council of our progress.”

Nodding, and giving what I could only imagine was a military salute, Dhelo said, “Yes sir.”

After Dhelo left the room, Borza turned to the Chief and me. “I apologize for my pilot; she lost two of her siblings in the attack
on Maltor Prime.”

“You have nothing to apologize for; I’m sure we’d react in much the same way.”

Before we could start talking again, we were interrupted by a commotion outside. For the sound of it, the guards were arguing with someone. “Ma’am, you can’t go in there!”

You can imagine my surprise when I heard Margo’s voice respond, “The hell I can’t!”

Seconds later the door burst open and Margo entered the room; I swear I saw a look of relief on her face when she saw the two aliens in the room. As the guards came in to remove her, Chief Hertle said, “Ma’am, what is the meaning of this?”

“It’s Eric’s daughter; her infection is getting worse.” Turning to me, Margo said, “I-I don’t know how much longer we can keep her alive.”

“Forgive me, but is the nature of your child’s injury?”

“Her boyfriend was changed by the gas; it turned him into a four-legged creature.” Turning to Borza, I said, “It bit my daughter and now she’s fighting an infection.”

“I am familiar with the creatures you speak of.” Looking at me, Borza said, “Take me to your child, I might be able to help save her.”

With Chief Hertel’s permission, I led Borza and the others out of the room. As we rushed to the infirmary, I looked back to find Margo speaking with Phiemu. I couldn’t tell what they were saying, but Phiemu nodded in agreement to something.

Once we reached the infirmary, which was thankfully empty, I made my way over to Olivia’s bedside. Her skin was bluer than it had been earlier, and I noticed a finger on her left hand was almost completely gone.

Before I could inquire about what was happening, Margo came forward and said, “She was doing fine until just a few minutes ago; then her temperature spiked.”

Turning to Borza, on the verge of freaking out, I said, “Please do whatever you can to save her.”

“I’m afraid there’s only one option left to us at this point.” Looking at me, Borza said, “But I must warn you; doing so will come at great cost.”

What could be costlier than doing nothing? “I don’t care what it costs; just save my daughter.”

“I can sympathize with wanting to do anything to save one’s offspring.” Focusing on me, Borza said, “If we do this, there will be no going back.”

Now I was starting to get worried; what would saving Olivia's life cost me. “What exactly are you going to do?”

“In order to save your daughter, we’ll have to turn her into a Maltorian.”
111111111111111111111.title: The Newcomers

1111111111111111111111.content:
I honestly wasn’t sure that I’d heard Borza correctly. “You want to make my daughter a... a... ?"

"Maltorian.” Nodding, Borza said, “In order to save her life; we must make her one of us. Or, rather, we must complete the transformation that was begun by our observer.”

Everything started to fall into place once Borza said that. Margo’s confusion over common idioms; the way she held up five fingers when saying the number four to how much she knew about our invaders – the Creel-whatever. Even the injections made sense now; especially how they were turning my daughter blue and causing a finger on each hand to wither. Feeling betrayed, I turned to Margo and said, “You’re one of them, aren’t you?”

“I know you have questions, Eric; once Olivia is safe, I promise that I’ll answer all of them.” Looking at me, Margo said, “But right now your daughter is dying, and the only way to save her life is to completely rewrite her genetic code. She will no longer be human, but she'll be alive.”

“This is not an easy decision to make, Eric Sheppard.” Standing on the other side of Olivia’s bed, Borza said, “But we must have an answer now; before it’s too late.”

I looked down at Olivia as she lay unconscious on the bed. Could I really save her by taking away her humanity? As I stood there, my thoughts turned to her mother and how quickly her cancer spread. Had these Mal-things offered to save her life in the same way, would I have gone through with it?”

I quickly realized that was a stupid question; thus arriving at my answer. Turning to Borza, I said, “Alright, do it. What happens now?”

“We must bring her to our vessel to finish the procedure.” Looking at me, Piemu said, “You are welcome to come with us if you’d like.”
1111111111111111111111.title: Deciding Olivia's Fate

11111111111111111111111.content:
Things moved quickly once I’d reached my decision; with help from Borza and Piemu, we brought Olivia from the infirmary to the yard. On the way there, Borza called ahead to have Dhelo prep the ship. Chief Hertel must’ve come back to the yard after we left; because I saw him standing in the yard overlooking the ship. “What’s going on here, Eric?”

“I don’t have time to explain, Chief.” As we ran past, I said, “I’m trying to save Olivia’s life.”

“I understand.”

While the rest of us went aboard the ship, Chief Hertel and the other officers started clearing the area. Margo and I were in the process of securing Olivia’s gurney when Dhelo walked out of the cockpit. “The engines are warmed up; and Command knows...”
Dhelo stopped speaking the moment she saw Margo standing in front of her; likewise, Margo stopped what she was doing as well. From the looks they were giving each other, I figured they knew each other. I didn’t realize how well until Margo walked over and gave Dhelo a passionate kiss on the lips.

After they kissed for a moment, Margo looked at Dhelo and said, “I-I can’t believe you’re here.”

“I could say the same thing about you, Sorain.”

Sorain? Stepping up to them, I looked at Margo and said, “Margo, do you know this woman?”

“Margo? Is that your human name?”

Ignoring Dhelo for a moment, Margo turned to me and said, “I guess you could say Dhelo is my ex-girlfriend.”

“So wait a minute; what you said about that blind date was real?”

I knew instantly, from the look on Dhelo’s face, that she hadn’t expected to hear that. Looking at Margo, I said, “Have you gone native, Sorain?”

After exchanging an annoyed look with me, Margo turned to Dhelo and said, “I was sent here to understand these people, Dhelo.”

Scoffing, Dhelo said, “I understand my ship pretty well; and I never thought about sleeping with it.”

As it became clear that Dhelo and Margo had some unfinished business, I was relieved when Borza stepped forward. “Dhelo, need I remind you we’re running short on time.”

“Sorry sir.” Exchanging a look with Margo, Dhelo said, “We’ll be airborne momentarily.”
11111111111111111111111.title: Boarding the Shuttle

111111111111111111111111.content:
While Borza followed Dhelo into the cockpit, I sat down on a seat along a bulkhead. Margo sat down next to me. “You may want to restrain yourself; Dhelo’s takeoffs were always a little rough.”

Following Margo’s lead, I strapped myself in just as Dhelo took off. Margo wasn’t kidding; the whole ship shook a little as we gained altitude. Turning to Margo, I said, “So I guess I should call you Sorain?”

“Only if you want to; feel free to call me Margo if you like.” Looking at me, Margo said, “Eric, I’m...”

“You lied to me, Margo.” Giving her an angry look, I said, “I trusted you, and you repaid that trust by lying to me.”

“I was under strict orders not to reveal myself to the local populace.” Sighing, Margo said, “If it makes you feel better, I hated having to do it. You and Olivia are one of the few humans that I genuinely cared for.”

“Then you don’t know us as well as you think.” Sighing, I said, “If you really cared about us, you wouldn’t have lied.”

“Do you have any idea what saving Olivia’s life almost cost me?” getting upset, Margo said, “Those vials I was injecting her with?
They contained a serum that would’ve returned me to my original form. Had the Mothership not arrived when it did, I could’ve easily been stuck as a human.”

“So wait, you’re actually human right now?” confused, I said, “That’s not just an elaborate disguise?”

“It’s all part of the preparations for an observer assignment.” Taking a breath, Margo said, “The members of my team, myself included, were transformed into humans prior to our assignment here.”

“How many people were on your team?”

“There were eight of us in total; I haven’t been able to contact any of them since the Creel arrived.” Sighing, Margo said, “I have a feeling I’m the only survivor.”

The shuttle shook again as we reached higher into the atmosphere. Dhelo’s voice came over the intercom, “We’re 5 minutes from space; we’ll be at the Mothership in 15 minutes.”

“There’s one thing I’d like to know.” Turning back to Margo, I said, “If those vials were meant for you, why did you use them on Olivia?”

“Because she saved me from that Uakari at the hospital – what used to be that foolish teenage boy.” Looking at me, Margo said, “She risked her life to save someone she barely knew; I knew I had to do the same.”

“Why did you keep me in the dark about what you were doing?” pausing, I said, “Don’t you think I deserved to know you were changing my daughter’s species?”

“I didn’t want to take the chance that you’d make me stop.”

“Why would I ask you to stop doing something that was saving her life?”

Before Margo could respond, Dhelo called over the intercom. “We’re approaching the Mothership.”

Standing up, Margo was the first to enter the cockpit. I guess I couldn’t blame her; she hadn’t seen her home in who knows how long. Coming up behind her, I got my first glimpse at the Maltorian’s spaceship; in low orbit around the moon. I was immediately reminded of the line from Contact, “They should have sent a poet.” There were no words to describe the sight before me. The ship had to be at least 25 miles across and shaped almost like a manta-ray.

“Does your entire species live on that ship?”

“That’s correct; all 1500 of us.” Standing next to me, Margo said, “I must say, it’s good to be home again.”

I stood at the back of the cockpit as Borza piloted the shuttle towards the raised section in the middle of the hull. As we got closer, I saw a hanger door open. Within seconds the shuttle had flown inside and the doors closed again.
111111111111111111111111.title: The Flight to the Ship

1111111111111111111111111.content:
The interior of the ship was, if it were possible, even more impressive than the exterior. The corridors were circular in shape and were light blue in color. As Margo and I followed Borza to their infirmary, I couldn’t help but notice the looks I was getting from the Maltorians as I passed by. I had to remind myself that I’d reacted the same way when their shuttle landed.

Once we arrived at the infirmary some people dressed in what looked like scrubs came out and brought Olivia inside. Turning to me, Borza said, “Your daughter is in good hands, Eric Sheppard.”

“Thank you, Borza.” Breathing a sigh of relief, I said, “Can I go in with her?”

“Of course.” Turning to Margo, he said, “There’s a medical unit waiting for you next door to implement the reversion.”

“Thank you, Overseer.” Looking at me, Margo said, “I’ll see you once I’m finished, Eric.”

As Borza walked off, I looked at Margo and said, “Is this ‘reversion’ going to make you Maltorian again?”

“That’s right.” Smiling, running a hand through her brunette hair, Margo said, “I’ve gotten used to having this hair, but it’ll be nice to see my true self in the mirror again.”

Before Margo turned to walk down the corridor, I pulled her into a hug. Once we’d hugged for a moment, I looked at her and said,
“Thank you Margo.”

“You’re welcome, Eric.”

Margo and I then parted ways; as I walked through the doorway into the infirmary. I was in awe of what I saw inside; everything was so futuristic, almost like something out of Star Trek. I spotted several Maltorians standing around a bed in the far corner; I walked over and found Olivia lying there.

I saw a series of needles sticking into different parts of her body; her skin slowly changing from white to an azure color with a mix of green. The more drastic physical changes had already started by the time I entered the room. Olivia’s hands and feet no longer resembled those of a human; she now had the same four toes and four fingers as every other Maltorian I’d seen.
Her skin color had finished changing within 5 minutes; followed by her slowly losing her hair. Next came the changes to her face; as her skull began to stretch out and take the shape of a Maltorian female.

The whole process took only 20 minutes; when it was over, there was nothing human left of Olivia. She was Maltorian now.

Pulling a chair up to her bed, I took her hand in mine and said, “I hope you’ll forgive me for this, Olivia.”

A Maltorian female came over to Olivia’s bed. “Your daughter will be asleep for at least eight of your hours, Eric Sheppard.”
Looking at me, she said, “Overseer Borza has provided you with temporary quarters if you’d like to get some rest.”

“T-Thank you.” Looking at her, I said, “I-Is there a place where I can sit down and think?”

“Of course; follow me to the promenade.”

After giving Olivia a kiss on her forehead, I followed the Maltorian out into the corridor and down to what I could only assume was an elevator. We entered and the Maltorian pressed a button with alien text on it - ⌿⍀⍜⋔⟒⋏⏃⎅⟒. Suddenly the elevator started moving; first vertically then horizontally.

It wasn’t long before the lift stop and the door opened up onto a large open area at the front of the ship. Stepping out of the lift, I found myself staring at a room filled with alien trees and plants; as well as several moderately sized ponds.
