There were several large windows in the front; each with a view of the Moon and Earth. Spotting a bench in the distance, I turned to the Maltorian and said, “Thank you for your help.”

“You’re welcome.”

As the lift door closed again; I started walking towards the bench; stopping to admire the plant life on the way. I was grateful to see that I was the only person in the area; which was good since I wasn’t in the mood to be gawked at right now.

****************************


I lost track of how long I’d been sitting on the bench; looking out the window at the Lunar surface. I knew I’d made the right decision to save Olivia; I just found myself worrying that she wouldn’t see it that way.

I was pulled from my thoughts by the sound of approaching footsteps. Great, just what I need. Without turning to face the unwelcome guest, I said, “I’d like to be alone right now; I’d appreciate if you left me alone.”

“Well okay then; I’ll leave if that’s what you want.”

I jumped to my feet when I heard that voice. Turning around, I found a female Maltorian smiling at me. Getting a look at her, I realized where I’d seen that smile before. “Margo?”
1111111111111111111111111.title: Olivia's Transformation

11111111111111111111111111.content:
I took the opportunity to get a get look at Margo in her rightful form. She was still the same height as before; but that’s where the similarities ended. Her skin was a more pronounced mixture of blue and green than I’d seen with Olivia, so I figured skin tone varied amongst Maltorians. Her outfit consisted of something akin to a short sleeve shirt, a vest, and some knee-length pants.

“What’s that phrase human’s use - in the flesh?” with a chuckle, gesturing to her body, Margo said, “This is what I looked like before I arrived on your world. Not bad, huh?”

I couldn’t help but think Margo looked appealing in her rightful form. Trying to shake some images from my mind, I said, “So now that you’re back, are you going to get back together with Dhelo?”

“I’m not sure; we had a nasty fight before I left for Earth.” Placing her hands on her waist, with a sigh, Margo said, “But I can tell you that I’m done with being undercover for a while.”

“I saw the way she looked at you in the shuttle; she may have acting upset, but there’s still something there.”

“We’ll see what happens.” Looking at me, she said, “May I connect you?”

“I think you meant to if you could join me.” Gesturing to the bench, I said, “Have a seat, I could use the company.”

As we both sat down, Margo said, “Your species’ verbal expressions are very confusing.” Looking at me, she said, “I’m sure I would be treading on hot water by the time my mission had been completed.”

I took that to mean she was worried about being found out but didn’t want to press her on it. Sitting back on the bench, I said, “It still bugs me that you lied to me, Margo.”

“You’re a police officer, Eric.” Turning to me, Margo said, “Surely you’ve had to conceal information about yourself as part of your job.”

I did participate in one undercover assignment when I was younger. “That’s not the same thing, Margo.”

“Think of it this way; if the Creel had never discovered your world, would you expect me to reveal myself?”

I wasn’t going to lie, she had me there. “I guess you have a point.”

“I was on Earth for almost a year; during which time I observed your society quite closely.” Taking a breath, Margo said, “Your species’ visions of contact with alien intelligence have a disturbing tendency to involve global conquest. You see yourselves killing anyone who doesn’t look like you; and yet you wonder why I don’t tell you that I’m different.”

I hadn’t thought of it that way; from Margo’s perspective she was taking her life in her hands every day. Here I was complaining that she didn’t trust a man she hardly knew. Looking at her, I said, “I’m sorry, Margo.”

“It’s alright, Eric; I forgive you.”

The two of us sat on the bench, watching the moon, for a while longer. Eventually I stood up and said, “I should probably turn in; I’ve been running on fumes for a while.”

“Yes; Borza told me he arranged for quarters for you.” Standing up, Margo said, “My quarters on the way, I’ll walk with you.”
11111111111111111111111111.title: Getting Reacquainted With Margo

111111111111111111111111111.content:
Margo led me down a long corridor before stopping outside of a closed door. Spotting something next to the door, I looked closer and saw the same alien writing from the elevator - ⌇⍜⍀⏃⟟⋏ ☍⟒☍⎐⏃⟟. Turning to Margo, I said, “Is that your language or something?”

“That’s right.” Reaching towards a keypad, Margo said, “It’s to identify these quarters as mine; it says Sorain Kekvai.”

Once Margo put in a 6 digit code, the door opened. I followed Margo inside and found myself inside a modest-sized cabin. There were some personal effects strewn around, but I mainly saw some furniture arranged around a small window looking out into space. I also saw a small, bunk-style bed built into the wall.

I spotted two more doors, one of which was closed, that likely led to other rooms. Turning to Margo, who was standing just inside the door, I said, “This reminds me of the apartment I had in college.”

“The units they give to the families are twice as big, but this suits my needs.” Looking at me, Margo said, “I apologize for the clutter, I haven’t been in here for almost a year.”

Aside from a few discarded pieces of clothing, I didn’t see anything that amounted to clutter. In fact, the place was immaculate when compared to Olivia’s bedroom. Looking at Margo, I said, “This is fine; you should see how messy Olivia’s bedroom would get.”

I felt as if I had a lump in my throat at the mention of Olivia. Walking over to the window, I stared out at the Earth in the distance. It looked so tiny and insignificant from here. Coming up behind me, Margo said, “If you’re worried about Olivia, you should know that you made the right decision?”

“Did I though?” turning to Margo, I said, “I made a life-altering decision without discussing it with her; now she’s going to wake up to find she’s not even human anymore.”

“She may be angry with you at first, but eventually she’ll realize you did it to save her life.”

“How would you feel if you woke up as a different...”

I stopped talking when I realized the absurdity of what I was about to say. Looking at me, a smirk on her face, Margo said, “Have you forgotten that I spent the last 11 months living as a human?”

“Sorry, I-I wasn’t thinking.” Sitting down on the couch, I said, “I could use a drink, do you have anything?”

“I have a bottle of guciragus in the stasis unit, but I don’t think it’s a good time for that.” Looking at me, Margo said, “This soon after the reversion, my digestive system isn’t ready for Maltorian beverages yet.”

“I’m not sure I’m ready for Maltorian beverages either.” Looking at her, I said, “What else do you have?”

“I can synthesize a bottle of scotch if you’d like.”

I wanted to ask what she meant by synthesizing, but I figured that could wait until later. “Scotch sounds great.”

After Margo went into the other room, I got up and looked around some more. I spotted what appeared to be some old, yet cared for, items on a shelf near the bed. Going closer, I saw what looked like a picture frame; with a young Maltorian standing in front of two adults. I quickly realized the young Maltorian was Margo.

Margo must’ve walked back into the room while I wasn’t looking; because she suddenly appeared next to me and said, “That’s the only picture I have left of my parents; they were killed in the Creel invasion.”

Turning to Margo, I saw a pained look in her eyes. “I’m sorry; it’s not easy losing your parents, especially at a young age.”

“It’s even worse when it’s my fault they’re dead."
111111111111111111111111111.title: Margo's Quarters

1111111111111111111111111111.content:
After the shocking twist, Margo and I saw down on the couch. Pouring some scotch into a glass, she drank it in one gulp before pouring another for her and one for me. Taking the glass, I said, “Do you want to explain how it was your fault?” glancing at the photo, I said, “You couldn’t have been older than 7 years old in that photo.”

“The Creelaxians attacked just days after my 7th birthday.” Taking another sip of the whiskey, Margo said, “Everyone was running for their lives; desperately trying to find a ship to get off-world.”

“My parents and I were running through our housing complex; when we came across my best friend Tar'ad and her family.” Sighing, Margo said, “The six of us ran through the streets towards the spaceport; only to be cut off when the bridge was destroyed.”

I had to admit it was interesting learning about an attack on another planet, but I made sure now to show it. “We hid in a nearby shop; as the Creel captured or transformed anyone they could find.” Taking a breath, Margo said, “Suddenly there was an explosion outside; I screamed and that brought the Uakari – the tall creatures from the hospital. They captured all of us and brought us to a nearby building.”

Feeling sympathy for Margo, I reached out to hold her hand as she continued. “They were transforming people into Gemsbok – a creature used for breeding the next generation of Creelaxians.” Fighting tears, Margo said, “I-I watched as they transformed Tar’ad into a Creelaxian child; I tried calling out to her as she was led past, but she just ignored me.”

“Margo, if you...”

“No, I-I want to do this; I-I haven’t let myself think about this for a long time.” Taking another sip, Margo said, “After that, I watched as everyone else was transformed into Gemsbok. As they were hooking her up to a machine, my mom tried her best to reassure me; only to scream in pain as she was forcibly changed.”

“I don’t remember much after that; only that eventually some Maltorian soldiers raided the building and rescued myself along with the remaining prisoners.” Putting the glass on the table, Margo started crying, as she said, “I-If I hadn’t screamed in fright; my parents and my best friend would be here today.”

“Margo, that wasn’t your fault.” Looking at her, I said, “You were a frightened child; I would have screamed as well if I were in your position.”

Margo leaned over and buried herself in my arms; crying as she did so. I wrapped my arms around her, unsure of what else I could do in this situation.

**************************


After she’d had a good cry, Margo went to clean up. Walking out of the bathroom, she looked at me and said, “I’m sorry about that; it’s just...seeing what happened on my world happening here; it’s like opening old wounds again.”

“You don’t need to apologize, Margo.” As she sat back down on the couch, I said, “If you don’t mind my asking, what happened after you were rescued?”

“The survivors were brought to the spaceport; where we boarded shuttles which brought us here.” Sighing, Margo said, “I was technically an orphan at that point, so I was taken in by another family. I lived with them until I was 17; at which point I joined the Observer Corp as an Initiate.”
1111111111111111111111111111.title: Margo's Story

11111111111111111111111111111.content:
When I woke up the next morning, I wasn’t surprised to find that I was dealing with a nasty hangover; thanks to Margo and me finishing off two bottles of scotch. Opening my eyes, I quickly realized that I was in Margo’s bed; but couldn’t find Margo. That changes when I looked down to find her asleep next to me; her head resting on my chest.

Dear God, I hope this isn’t what it looks like. Taking a peek under the covers, my fears were confirmed when I saw that we were both naked. Suddenly the events of last night flashed before my eyes; Margo and I were drinking when she suddenly leaned over and kissed me. I reciprocated the kiss and we soon moved things to the bed.

Sitting up, I started shaking Margo to wake up. “Margo, wake up!”

After a few seconds of nothing, Margo started to stir. “W-What’s going on?” sitting up, she realized where she was. “Eric, why are we in bed together?”

“All I remember is us kissing and moving to the bed; after that, everything’s a blur.”

“I have no memory of that at all.” putting a hand on her forehead, Margo said, “God, my head is killing me.”

Climbing out of bed, I found where my pants had ended up and put them on. Turning to Margo, who had covered herself with the sheet, I said, “What are we going to do about this, Margo?”

“I don’t think there’s anything we can do.” Climbing out of bed, the sheet wrapped around her, Margo said, “The chances of me getting pregnant after a reversion are almost zero.”

I hadn’t even thought of that; what if, by some small chance, I ended up getting Margo pregnant. What would a Maltorian-Human child look like? “I need to get cleaned up; I have to be there when Olivia wakes up.”

Heading towards the closed door, Margo said, “Follow me, I’ll show you how to use the cleaning unit.”

*************************


The cleaning unit, despite all the weird alien stuff, was nothing more than a glorified shower. There was a touch panel on the wall to activate it. Once I was finished, I walked out to the main room as Margo came out of the kitchen area. “The cleaning unit is free.”

“That’s okay.” Putting on her pants, Margo said, “Maltorians only wash themselves every other day; otherwise our skin dries out.”’

“I need to know something.” Looking at Margo, I said, “Does what we did...change anything?”

“What do you mean?”

“I mean does it change our...relationship?” trying my best not to sound like a high schooler after his first kiss, I said, “I’d be lying if I said I didn’t care about you; especially after everything you did for Olivia.”

“I care about you too, Eric.” Sighing, Margo said, “But don’t worry; Maltorians sometimes have sex as a way to blow off steam. What we did last night doesn’t change anything.”

I tried my best not to be insulted by the notion that Margo had used me for stress relief. “I suppose I should go check up on Olivia.”

“About that.” Putting on her shoes, Margo said, “The infirmary called while you were in the other room; Olivia’s awake and asking to speak with you.”

“How did they know I was...never mind.” Sighing, I said, “I don’t even know what I’m going to say to her.”

“You’d better figure it out quickly.” Looking at me, Margo said, “I could hear her in the background, and she didn’t sound very happy.”
11111111111111111111111111111.title: The Next Morning

111111111111111111111111111111.content:
Margo brought me down to the infirmary a few minutes later. As I stood outside, I looked at her and said, “What would you
want someone to say to you if you were in this position?”

“You’re her father, so probably something about how you’ll still love her regardless of her species.”

“I suppose that will work.” Sighing, I said, “Do you want to come in with me?”

“I’d love to, but I have to meet with Overseer Borza.” Pausing, Margo said, “It seems that I’m the only one of my team who’s
made contact.”

“Well then, wish me luck.”

“Good luck, Eric.”

Once I walked into the infirmary, I saw that there was no one else in the room except for Olivia. They must’ve gotten tired of her yelling at them. As I walked closer, I realized that didn't have a ton of experience with Maltorians. But I did have experience with Olivia; and from the look that she was giving me, she was probably wishing I was dead.

She was sitting up in bed, staring daggers at me. “Good morning, honey.”

“Don’t you ‘good morning honey’ me!” gesturing to her blue appearance, Olivia said, “I’m a monster! All these other monsters keep telling me that this was all your idea.”

“You’re not a monster, Olivia.” Stepping a little closer, I said, “You’re a Maltorian.”

“I don’t care what it’s called, Daddy; I don’t want to be one!” looking at me, she said, “Tell them to make me human again!”

“I can’t do that, sweetie; I did this to save your life.” Reaching out to touch her, I said, “If it weren’t for this procedure, you would have died from that infection.”

Pulling her arm away from me, she said, “You took the word of the creatures that came to invade us?”

“The Maltorians didn’t invade; they’re here to stop the ones that did.” Taking her hand in mine, I said, “If there was any other option to keep you both alive, and human, I would’ve taken it. I didn’t want to lose you, Liv; it would’ve been so much worse than losing your mother.”

That was enough to break through the intense anger that Olivia was feeling. Reaching forward, she wrapped arms around me and started crying into my shoulder. “I’m scared, Daddy; I don’t even know what I am anymore.”

“You’re my daughter, and I love you.” Holding her close, I said, “No matter what, that will never change.”
111111111111111111111111111111.title: Seeing Olivia

1111111111111111111111111111111.content:
It took a while but I managed to calm Olivia down to the point where she was no longer crying. One of the nurses had returned with a mirror; giving Olivia a chance to see what she looked like now. I was sitting in a chair watching as she moved her face around to get a good look at it. “Why does my skull look so weird?”

“That’s just the way they evolved, I guess.” Looking at her, I said, “Are you going to be okay, sweetie?”

“This is going to take some getting used to; especially now that I only have four fingers and toes.” Putting the mirror down, Olivia said, “I’m sorry about earlier; I-I guess I was just in shock. Now that I’ve had time to think about it, you made the right choice.”

Leaning over to hug her, I said, “Thank you, sweetie.”

“That being said, I would’ve preferred to have a say in the matter.” Breaking the hug, Olivia said, “That way I don’t wake up and suddenly find myself turned into a blue alien.”

“I promise next time that you’ll have a say in the matter.”

“So, uh, what happened after the hospital?” looking at me, Olivia said, “The last thing I remember is shooting that thing going after Margo.”

I proceeded to explain how we made our way to the prison and how we lost several people to the aliens. I decided it was best not to tell her about Margo just yet; giving her time to process everything.

********************************


Olivia and I kept talking for a little while until a group of three Maltorians entered the room. One of them was dressed in different garments then the others. He walked up to me and said, “Eric Sheppard; I’m Vakzan Ehel, I’m the Senior Minister of the Ruling Council.” Gesturing to the other two, he said, “This is Jervix Telfani and his wife Katura.”

“It’s a pleasure to meet all of you.” Looking at him, I said, “What can I do for you?”

“We are here about your daughter, Olivia Sheppard.” Looking at me, he said, “I’m afraid we can’t let her leave.”
1111111111111111111111111111111.title: Talking With Olivia

11111111111111111111111111111111.content:
Upon hearing that, Olivia wrapped her arms around me and held tight. “No! I want to go home!”

“Why can’t she come home with me?” placing an arm around Olivia, I said, “She’s my daughter.”

“She’s Maltorian now.” Looking at us, Vakzan said, “She must learn what it means to be one of us.”

I suppose Vakzan did have a point; after all, there weren’t many Maltorians left. They had every right to try and keep their culture alive. Turning to look at Olivia, who was still holding me tightly, I said, “It’ll be okay, sweetie.”

“Daddy, I don’t want to stay here.”

“I don’t want you to stay here either.” Gesturing to Vakzan and the others, I said, “But Vakzan has a point; with so few Maltorians left, it’s only fair to ensure you know what it means to be one.”

“What if that means forgetting what it means to be human?”

“That will never happen.” Pointing to her head, I said, “No matter what they teach you, you’ll always remember what it means to be human.”

With some hesitation, Olivia separated from me and walked towards the others. Placing his hands on her shoulders, Jervix looked at me and said, “Don’t worry, Eric Sheppard; my wife and I will endeavor to be good role models for her.”

I watched as the Maltorians led Olivia out of the room; leaving me alone with my thoughts. It was only after they left that it occurred to me how strange it was that he’d said that. [i}Maybe it’s a cultural thing; I’ll have to talk with Margo about it.{/i}
11111111111111111111111111111111.title: The Maltorians Take Olivia

111111111111111111111111111111111.content:
It took some time to find my way back to the shuttle bay, but I eventually made it with the help of a young boy. After thanking the boy for his help, I walked into the bay to find several more ships were present that hadn’t been there the night before. I also noticed a fair number of containers stacked on the hanger floor.

I wonder what all this is for. Walking towards the shuttle, I saw Margo step out with Dhelo close behind. As I got closer, I noticed Dhelo giving me a strange look – as if she was upset with me about something. Once she walked off, I went over to Margo as she was surveying some of the containers. “What was with Dhelo’s look just now?”

“She’s not very pleased that I slept with a human last night.” Sighing, Margo said, “She thinks its just further proof that I’ve gone native.”

“Why would you tell Dhelo, of all people, that we slept together?”

“Maltorians aren’t as close-minded as humans when it comes to sex.” Looking at me, Margo said, “We’re not ashamed to tell others about our sexual encounters.”

“I wish you would’ve talked with me first.”

“The next time we sleep together, I promise to talk with you before I tell anyone.”

“Thank you, that’s all...wait, there’s going to be a next time?”

“I still don’t remember a whole lot, but I can tell you that I remember enjoying the experience.” With a smile, Margo said, “I’d very much like to do it again sometime.”

I had to contain my excitement over the fact that Margo was considering sleeping with me again. Taking a breath, I said, “That still doesn’t explain why you had to tell Dhelo. I mean, she’s your ex after all.”

“Ex or not, she’s still one of my closest friends.” Pausing, Margo said, “We may have been a terrible couple, but we still care about each other.”

I knew enough about people to realize Margo wasn’t being entirely truthful with me. Looking at her, I said, “There’s something you’re not telling me.”

“Dhelo informed me that she’s bonded with another woman named Levan.”

“Bonded? What’s that mean?”

“To put it in terms you’d understand; she’s engaged.”

Hearing that, I placed a hand on Margo’s shoulder and said, “I’m sorry to hear that, Margo.”

“There’s nothing I can do about it now.” Sighing, Margo bent down to examine a container and said, “It certainly makes my decision to leave the Observer Corp that much easier.”

“You’re leaving the Observer Corp? Why?”

“Given my experiences with your species, I figured my talents would be best used on Earth.” Looking at me, Margo said, “If the Chief will allow it, I’m hoping to be the Camp’s doctor.”

Looking at the containers, some of which were being loaded onto the ships, I said, “Do these containers have medical supplies in them?”

“Most of them do, but not all. Some of them have weapons and technology to fight the Creel.” Gesturing to a large container, easily taller than myself, Margo said, “That one contains a fusion generator; so we can provide clean power to the Camp.”

*****************************


It took about 20 minutes for everything to loaded onto the four ships. As Margo and I took our seats in the cockpit of one of the shuttles, behind the pilot, I looked to her and said, “Assuming, of course, that Chief Hertel accepts your offer; how do you think people will feel about you being their doctor?”

“I’m sure there’s going to be a period of adjustment, but I’m sure everything will be fine.” Looking at me, Margo said, “I know I’ll have at least one friend down there.”

“You’ll make plenty of friends down there, Margo.”

As the ships took off, Margo turned to me and said, “I almost forgot; how did it go with Olivia?”

“She was pretty angry with me, but I think she’s getting past it.” Sighing, I said, “Some guy named Vakzan wouldn’t let me take her home; saying she has to learn what it means to be Maltorian.”

As the ships cleared the bay, Margo said, “I’m sure she’ll be home in a few days.”

“I hope so.” Sighing, I said, “Before I forget; one of the Maltorians who took Olivia said something about being a good role model. What do you think he meant by that?”

After years of experience, I knew when someone was trying to hide something. I could easily tell Margo was trying to hide something, but couldn't figure out what it was. Looking at me, she said, “It just means they’ll do their best to ensure Olivia learns about Maltorian society.”
111111111111111111111111111111111.title: The Shuttle Bay

1111111111111111111111111111111111.content:
The shuttle flight back to Earth passed without incident; allowing me the chance to view my home planet from space. I wasn’t sure why, but there were a few moments where my hand sought out Margo’s.

It was just after noon when the ships landed inside the Prison compound. As we got out of the ship, we saw a large crowd forming. I suddenly saw a familiar face running towards me from the crowd – it was David. Looking at me, he said, “Where’s Margo, is she with you?”

Coming up beside me, Margo knelt down and said, “I’m right here, sweetie.”

Unfortunately, David wasn’t ready to hear Margo’s voice coming from a blue-green woman with an elongated cranium. He took one look at her and ran off screaming. Margo was about to take off after him, but I stopped her and said, “Give him some time to process this, Margo.”

I could tell that Margo was hurt by David’s reaction, but she didn’t say anything. Just then Chief Hertle walked over to us.
“Piemu told me you guys were coming back with some supplies.” Looking around, he said, “Where’s Margo?”

Extending her hand, Margo said, “I’m right here, Chief.”

I had to remind myself that Chief Hertle hadn’t been present when Margo’s real identity had been revealed. “Margo?” looking her over, Chief Hertle said, “Wh-Why do you look like a Maltorian?”

Before I could speak, Margo told Chief Hertle everything about her mission on Earth. “My real name is Sorain Kekvai; but if it makes you feel more comfortable, you can continue calling me Margo.”

“Well Margo, I think it’s my turn to give you some good news.” Looking at Margo, Chief Hertle said, “You may not be the last surviving member of your team.”

I watched as Margo’s eyes bugged out in shock. “What?”

“A young woman arrived early this morning with an infant.” Pausing, Chief Hertle said, “She didn’t say much; only that she was looking for you.”
1111111111111111111111111111111111.title: Back to Earth

11111111111111111111111111111111111.content:
Chief Hertle led Margo and me through the prison to the infirmary; Margo received some looks on the way, but she didn’t react. The infirmary was empty except for a young woman nursing a baby in the corner. Taking one look at Margo, the woman stepped back and said, “What’s going on here?”

“Chief Hertle said you were looking for me?” Stepping forward, Margo said, “My name’s Margo.”

If Margo expected the woman to react like David, she was disappointed. The woman took one look at Margo and said, “Oh my God; it’s true.”

Margo gave me a confused look before turning her attention back to the woman. “How do you know my name?”

“After the aliens started attacking, I was told to come here and say that Khals Hunza sent me.”

I heard Margo give an audible gasp when she heard that name. Looking at her, I said, “Does that name mean anything to you?”

“Khals Hunza was a member of my observation team; he went dark about a month after we arrived on Earth.” Turning to the woman, Margo said, “How do you know that name?”

“He was my fiancée.” Gesturing to the baby, the woman said, “He’s also my son’s father.”
11111111111111111111111111111111111.title: Gone Native

111111111111111111111111111111111111.content:
Once everyone had gotten over their shock, the woman proceeded to explain everything. Her name was Jessica Mishner; she’d met Khals Hunza, or Kevin Anderson, at a party 12 months earlier. They hit it off quite quickly; with Jessica finding out she was pregnant about 2 months after they met. He proposed to her shortly after.

We were all sitting in the infirmary as she told her story. When she was finished, Margo said, “You had no clue that Khals...Kevin wasn’t what he seemed to be?”

“In retrospect, there were certain things that were odd; but I didn’t realize it at the time.” Looking at us, Jessica said, “I just thought he was really sweet, I had no idea he was actually an alien.”

“When did he finally come clean to you?”

“It wasn’t until after those other aliens started attacking.” Turning to Margo, Jessica said, “He detected the distress call you’d sent out; and thought it was a good idea to head towards it. I asked him why he was so insistent we come here; so he explained everything – his mission, who he really was, etc.”

“Did he tell you why he deserted the team?”

“He said something about feeling disenchanted with your species’ way of life.” Pausing, Margo said, “He wanted to start over on a new world.”

“That sounds like Khals.” Taking a breath, Margo said, “I’m hesitant to ask; but what happened to him?”

“We were about an hour from here when those creatures attacked.” Holding her son close, Jessica said, “We came across some people having car trouble; he went to help when an alien ship landed. I could only watch as they captured him and the three other people he was helping. I hid for a while until I decided to make my way here on foot.”

Neither Margo nor I wanted to tell Jessica what fate had befallen her fiancé. Looking at her, I said, “You’re safe now, Jessica; that’s all that matters.”

“I-I just wish Kevin was here with me.”
111111111111111111111111111111111111.title: The Woman's Story

1111111111111111111111111111111111111.content:
Chief Hertle and I decided to leave Margo to chat with Jessica alone. As we walked through the halls, he turned to me and said, “You left so quickly last night; I never had a chance to ask what was going on.”

“The Maltorians had a way to save Olivia’s life; but it required bringing her to their ship.” Sighing, I said, “It also required a major sacrifice on her part.”

Chief Hertle had known Olivia since she was little; he considered her a surrogate daughter. Looking at me, he said, “What kind of sacrifice? Is she alright?”

“They had to turn her into a Maltorian.” Taking a breath, I said, “She’s no longer human.”

“You let them do that to her?”

“It was that or let her die; what did you expect me to do?”

“I suppose that’s a valid point.” Sighing, Chief Hertle said, “How did she take it?”

“She didn’t take it well at all; she was angry with me for a while.”

“Why didn’t she come back with Margo and you?”

“The Governing Council said she needed to stay on the ship; to learn what it means to be Maltorian.” Leaning against a wall, I said, “They assured me that I could see her if a few days.”

“I just hope you made the right decision, Eric.”

“So do I, Chief.”
1111111111111111111111111111111111111.title: Chatting with the Chief

11111111111111111111111111111111111111.content:
It was almost dusk when I walked back into the prison; having spent most of the afternoon chatting with some of the Maltorians. I was becoming aware of some hostility towards the Maltorians; apparently the human predilection towards racism also applied to alien species. There weren’t any physical confrontations but some came close. I started to worry about Olivia and how people might treat her when she returned.

I was starting to get hungry as I walked inside; which gave me an idea to go check on Margo. I walked through the halls, occasionally stepping aside to let some inmates pass, on my way to the infirmary. Going inside I saw a woman in her early 20s applying a bandage to an inmate’s arm. Walking up to the nurse, I said, “Could you tell me where Margo is?”

“Why are you looking for that blue freak?” looking at me, the inmate said, “How do we know they’re here to help us?”

Before I could respond, the nurse turned to me and said, “I think she set up shop in the Administrative Wing.”

“Thank you.” Turning to the inmate, I said, “Better watch your tone, buddy; or you’ll end up outside the prison walls.”

Walking out of the infirmary, I took the stairs up to the Administrative Wing. It took a moment to find her, but I soon found her in an office at the end of the hall. I walked inside to find her covering David with a blanket as he slept on a cot. Leaning against the wall, I said, “I’m guessing you two patched things up?”

“He came by the infirmary a few hours ago; gave me a flower as his way of an apology.” Walking over to me, Margo said, “After everything that’s happened; between losing his grandparents and not knowing if his parents are alive, he was just shocked to see me like this.”

“That sentiment seems to be going around; it seems there are already people tossing around derogatory terms about you and the Maltorians.”

“I noticed a little of that earlier, but I just shrugged it off.” Sighing, Margo said, “It’s not the first time I’ve experienced that on this planet; and I’m certain it’s not going to be the last.”

Looking at David, asleep in the corner, I said, “With everything going on, perhaps it would be best if I stayed here with you two.”

“Why?” confused, Margo said, “I can take care of myself, Eric; I survived on this planet for almost a year without your help.”

“I know, but I’m trying to say you shouldn’t have to.” Taking her hand, I said, “You’re in danger here, Margo.”

“We’re all in danger, Eric; so long as the Creel are interested in this planet.” Removing her hand from mine, Margo said, “Why are you so focused on keeping me safe?”

“You’re my only connection to Olivia; you can help me understand what she’s going through.” Looking at her, I said, “Plus I’d be lying if I said I didn’t care about you.”

“I care about you too, Eric.” Gesturing to David, Margo said, “But I have to think about David now; people might not take too kindly about us being involved.”

“We’re both adults, Margo; who cares what other people think.”

Margo just stood in front of me for a moment; thinking things over in her head. Before I could react, she wrapped her hands around my neck and kissed me. I reciprocated the kiss and the two of us made out for a few moments; until I started to take off her shirt. Breaking the kiss, Margo removed my hands from her shirt and said, “As much as I want to, I don’t think we should do this with David in the room.”

“I saw an empty office across the hall; we could go in there if you want.”

Grabbing a sleeping bag and some pillows, Margo said, “Last one cleans a garlock sty with his tongue!"

As Margo ran out of the room, I inferred the meaning of her phrase – last one there is a rotten egg. Going out after her, the two of us went into the empty office and closed the door. It wasn’t long before we were both naked and making love inside the sleeping bag.
11111111111111111111111111111111111111.title: Later On

111111111111111111111111111111111111111.content:
Margo and I were snuggling in the sleeping bag after an hour of lovemaking. With everything that’s happened, I still found it hard to imagine that I was sharing a bed with an alien female. I was brought back to reality as Margo turned over so she was resting on my chest. Looking at me, a smile on her face, she said, “That’s the best I’ve had in a long time.”

“I’m glad you think so.” Running a hand down her back, I said, “You’re actually the first woman I’ve slept with since my wife died.”

With a smirk, Margo said, “That certainly puts some pressure on me.”

“Don’t worry, you were amazing.”

We lay there for a few more minutes until Margo climbed out of the sleeping bag. “I should probably go check on David; see if he wants to get some dinner.”

As Margo got dressed, I said, “Have you basically taking him in?”

“Yeah, I guess I have.” Putting her shirt on, Margo said, “I know what it’s like to lose family to the Creel; I have to try and help him through this.”

**********************


I followed Margo and David through the prison to the mess hall; where we all got some looks, both good and bad, from the people in the room. Once the three of us got our food, Margo made a bee-line towards a group of Maltorians sitting in the corner. I went to join them despite my concerns about there being an armed guard with them.

I had just sat down to eat when a young man, wearing a corrections officer uniform, came into the room. “I’m looking for Eric Sheppard, is he here?”

Casting a look towards Margo, I quietly got up and walked over. “I’m Eric Sheppard.”

“Chief Hertle needs you in the prison yard; a patrol from town returned with some survivors.”

I followed the man to the prison yard where I noticed a group of people getting out of a bus. I watched as Chief Hertle and some officers walked towards them. I wanted to ask why I was called for this; until I saw a familiar face in the crowd. “Emily!”

Emily Rogers was Olivia’s best friend. I ran over to her; grateful to see that her family was in one piece. Wrapped in a blanket, she looked at me and said, “Mr. Sheppard?”
111111111111111111111111111111111111111.title: An Hour Later

1111111111111111111111111111111111111111.content:
As soon as Emily saw me, she wrapped her arms around me as if I would disappear otherwise. Even Margo, in the throes of passion, didn't squeeze me tighter.

"It's good to see a familiar face, Detective," Mrs. Rogers said, "especially yours."

"Likewise," I replied. "Glad to see you all have survived this. Come on, let's get you settled in."

"Is Olivia here?" Emily asked. "Did she make it?"

Damn. I'd hoped I would have had more time to explain. "She's alive," I told her, "but not here. She had to go somewhere else. It's too complicated to go into now." Especially with the anti-Maltorian sentiment running around, I thought.

1221.content:
When the Creelaxians invade a planet, they capture the local inhabitants and transform them. They’re transformed into one of three forms; depending on the needs at that moment:

Gharial (Human nickname – Hounds)

The gharial are similar in height and weight to Terran bulldogs. They have a long snout with rows of sharp teeth. They have two sets of eyes; both of which can detect body heat. There are three sharp claws on foot, and spines protruding from their backs.
Their mouths contain bacteria that, if left untreated, will kill a victim within 2 days. In contrasts to their former species’ the

The gharial are not considered sentient; instead, they’re driven solely by an instinct to hunt.

Uakari (Human nickname – Soldiers)

The Uakari bear a resemblance to primitive Creelaxians; the only difference being a shorter stature and sharp horns running up their nasal ridge. Unlike the Gharial, they can’t detect body heat. Their lungs are considerably larger than Terrans and their hearts have 6 chambers instead of 4; giving them increased endurance.

They retain none of their former personalities and intelligence; as they are subconsciously driven to serve the Creelaxians.

Gemsbok (Human nickname – Breeders)

The sole use of the Gemsbok is as breeding stock for the Creelaxians. In contrast to the Gharial and Uakari; the Gemsbok resembles a combination of Creelaxian and Human, the appearance of a human female with slight skin discoloration.

While the Creel use both males and females; the Gemsbok are female in appearance. They spend their considerably shortened lives attached to a machine that helps to nourish them while the Creel offspring develops. This machine covers the Gemsbok from the waist down.

A Gemsbok gestates for 14 days; after 5 gestational periods they’re retired (killed). There is a small window of opportunity after the transformation where the former human is aware of what's happening to them. After about an hour, their mind is taken over by the overwhelming urge to serve the Creelaxians.

info.brief_description: A Police Officer and his teenage daughter try to survive an alien invasion
info.description:
Officer Eric Sheppard was just getting off work for the evening; coming home to find his daughter in her room with her boyfriend. After an altercation, he finds himself drawn into the start of a global alien invasion.

Rules:
1. Use proper grammar
2. Be creative with storylines but keep close to the original idea.
3. Use the 1st person perspective (I, I'm, I'll, etc) - keep it in Eric's POV
4. I reserve the right to edit, and/or/ remove chapters.
